Post ID:3944
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-01-01 11:39:05
Subject:Jan. 2006 Political Prisoner Events
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.prolibertadweb.com
ProLibertad@...
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

This ProLibertad Freedom Campaign Activity Digest consists of the following:

1. Oscar Lopez Rivera's 63rd Birthday Announcement.

2. Vieques Political Prisoner Jose Velez Acosta isgoing to be free Jan. 
27th, 2006 Announcement.

3. Assata/Cuban5/Filiberto Ojeda Rios Event in Harlem.

4. Sat. Jan. 7th, 2006 Support the Return of Basque Political Prisoners to 
Euskal Herrira
from the French & Spanish States
_______________________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters
to join us in wishing Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Oscar Lopez Rivera a
HAPPY BIRTHDAY AND HAPPY THREE KINGS!!

On January 6th, 2006, Oscar will be turning 63 years old!!  We encourage all
freedom-loving people to write to Oscar and let him know that people are
thinking of him.

Oscar Lopez Rivera
#87651-024
U.S. Penitentiary
P.O. Box 12015
Terre Haute, IN 47801

Oscar Lopez Rivera was born in San Sebastian, Puerto Rico on January 6,
1943. At the age of 12, he moved to Chicago with his family. He was a
well-respected community activist and a prominent independence leader for
many years prior to his arrest. Oscar was one of the founders of the Rafael
Cancel Miranda High School, now known as the Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos High
School and the Juan Antonio Corretjer Puerto Rican Cultural Center. He was a
community organizer for the Northwest Community Organization (NCO), ASSPA,
ASPIRA and the 1st Congregational Church of Chicago. He helped to found
FREE, (a half-way house for convicted drug addicts) and ALAS (an educational
program for Latino prisoners at Stateville Prison in Illinois).

He was active in various community struggles, mainly in the area of health
care, employment and police brutality. He also participated in the
development of the Committee to Free the Five Puerto Rican Nationalists. In
1975, he was forced underground, along with other comrades. He was captured
on May 29, 1981, after 5 years of being persecuted by the FBI as one of the
most feared fugitives from US "justice".

Oscar, who has a daughter named Clarissa, is currently serving a 55-year
sentence for seditious conspiracy and other charges. He was convicted of
conspiracy to escape along with Jaime Delgado, (a veteran independence
leader), Dora Garcia, (a prominent community activist) and Kojo
Bomani-Sababu, a New Afrikan political prisoner.

Oscar was one of 12 Puerto Rican political prisoners offered some form of
leniency by the Clinton Administration in the fall of 1999. According to the
Chicago Sun Times, he "declined the president's offer, which still would
have him left with 10 years to serve on conspiracy to escape charges. Now he
faces at least 20 more years in prison. His sister, Zenaida Lopez, said he
turned the offer down because he would be on parole. 'Accepting what they
are offering him is like prison outside of prison,' she said. Zenaida Lopez
said her brother 'was in total agreement' with the decision of the 11 others
to take the conditional clemency." Oscar is presently in prison in Terre
Haute, Indiana and his release date is 7/27/2027.
_______________________________________________________________________________

Vieques Political Prisoner Jose Velez Acosta is scheduled to be released on
Jan. 27th, 2006 from prison.  We encourage people to write to Jose as well
and to wish him a happy and speedy reintegration back into society.

Jose Velez Acosta  #23883-069
Jose Velez Acosta has family in Puerto Rico and the Bronx.  He has three
daughters who live with their mother in Springfield, Massachusetts. He was
sentenced to 33 months in jail.  He will be released on 1/27/2006.

Jos� A. V�lez Acosta
#23883-069
FCC United States Penitentiary
P.O. Box 1033
Coleman, Florida 33521-1033
_______________________________________________________________________________

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition
_______________________________________________________________________________

Saturday, January 7, 2006

Solidarity Picket to Support the Return  of Basque Political Prisoners to 
Euskal Herrira from the French & Spanish States

Permanent Mission of Spain to the UN 823 UN Plaza (345 E. 46th St.)

11:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.

Join NYC Jericho, ProLibertad and others in supporting the Basque people's 
demand
to bring the Basque Prisoners to the Basque Country

For more information, please call 718-220-6004

Basque Society Moves for Prisoners' Rights

On Saturday, Nov. 26 2005, representatives of 29 Basque political, trade 
union, and social organizations met at the Ibaeta University Campus in 
Donostia in order to address the issue of Basque Political Prisoners.

They agreed on a document denouncing the consequences of the policy of 
prisoner dispersal and demanding the Spanish and French governments 
recognize the representatives of the political prisoners and engage with 
them so that the Basque Political Prisoners Collective (EPPK) may take part 
in the ongoing political process. They agree that supporting the prisoners' 
rights is an essential step towards conflict resolution. The manifesto will 
be put to public institutions as a motion.

They also made a joint call to demonstrate on Jan. 7, 2006 in Bilbo, under 
the banner of "Euskal Presoak Euskal Herrira, Dagozkien Eskubideen Jabe" 
(Bring the Basque Prisoners to the Basque Country, Acknowledge Their Rights)

On behalf of the Basque Pro-Amnesty movement and the organizations at the 
Ibaeta Forum, we ask that, together with the broad representation of Basque 
society, you support the demonstration.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling on all our allies and supporters
to join us in wishing Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Oscar Lopez Rivera a
HAPPY BIRTHDAY AND HAPPY THREE KINGS!!

On January 6th, 2006, Oscar will be turning 63 years old!!  We encourage all
freedom-loving people to write to Oscar and let him know that people are
thinking of him.

Oscar Lopez Rivera
#87651-024
U.S. Penitentiary
P.O. Box 12015
Terre Haute, IN 47801

Oscar Lopez Rivera was born in San Sebastian, Puerto Rico on January 6,
1943. At the age of 12, he moved to Chicago with his family. He was a
well-respected community activist and a prominent independence leader for
many years prior to his arrest. Oscar was one of the founders of the Rafael
Cancel Miranda High School, now known as the Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos High
School and the Juan Antonio Corretjer Puerto Rican Cultural Center. He was a
community organizer for the Northwest Community Organization (NCO), ASSPA,
ASPIRA and the 1st Congregational Church of Chicago. He helped to found
FREE, (a half-way house for convicted drug addicts) and ALAS (an educational
program for Latino prisoners at Stateville Prison in Illinois).

He was active in various community struggles, mainly in the area of health
care, employment and police brutality. He also participated in the
development of the Committee to Free the Five Puerto Rican Nationalists. In
1975, he was forced underground, along with other comrades. He was captured
on May 29, 1981, after 5 years of being persecuted by the FBI as one of the
most feared fugitives from US "justice".

Oscar, who has a daughter named Clarissa, is currently serving a 55-year
sentence for seditious conspiracy and other charges. He was convicted of
conspiracy to escape along with Jaime Delgado, (a veteran independence
leader), Dora Garcia, (a prominent community activist) and Kojo
Bomani-Sababu, a New Afrikan political prisoner.

Oscar was one of 12 Puerto Rican political prisoners offered some form of
leniency by the Clinton Administration in the fall of 1999. According to the
Chicago Sun Times, he "declined the president's offer, which still would
have him left with 10 years to serve on conspiracy to escape charges. Now he
faces at least 20 more years in prison. His sister, Zenaida Lopez, said he
turned the offer down because he would be on parole. 'Accepting what they
are offering him is like prison outside of prison,' she said. Zenaida Lopez
said her brother 'was in total agreement' with the decision of the 11 others
to take the conditional clemency." Oscar is presently in prison in Terre
Haute, Indiana and his release date is 7/27/2027.
_______________________________________________________________________________

Vieques Political Prisoner Jose Velez Acosta is scheduled to be released on
Jan. 27th, 2006 from prison.  We encourage people to write to Jose as well
and to wish him a happy and speedy reintegration back into society.

Jose Velez Acosta  #23883-069
Jose Velez Acosta has family in Puerto Rico and the Bronx.  He has three
daughters who live with their mother in Springfield, Massachusetts. He was
sentenced to 33 months in jail.  He will be released on 1/27/2006.

Jos� A. V�lez Acosta
#23883-069
FCC United States Penitentiary
P.O. Box 1033
Coleman, Florida 33521-1033

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition

Basque Society Moves for Prisoners' Rights

On Saturday, Nov. 26 2005, representatives of 29 Basque political, trade 
union, and social organizations met at the Ibaeta University Campus in 
Donostia in order to address the issue of Basque Political Prisoners.

They agreed on a document denouncing the consequences of the policy of 
prisoner dispersal and demanding the Spanish and French governments 
recognize the representatives of the political prisoners and engage with 
them so that the Basque Political Prisoners Collective (EPPK) may take part 
in the ongoing political process. They agree that supporting the prisoners' 
rights is an essential step towards conflict resolution. The manifesto will 
be put to public institutions as a motion.

They also made a joint call to demonstrate on Jan. 7, 2006 in Bilbo, under 
the banner of "Euskal Presoak Euskal Herrira, Dagozkien Eskubideen Jabe" 
(Bring the Basque Prisoners to the Basque Country, Acknowledge Their Rights)

On behalf of the Basque Pro-Amnesty movement and the organizations at the 
Ibaeta Forum, we ask that, together with the broad representation of Basque 
society, you support the demonstration.

Basque Society Moves for Prisoners' Rights

On Saturday, Nov. 26 2005, representatives of 29 Basque political, trade
union, and social organizations met at the Ibaeta University Campus in
Donostia in order to address the issue of Basque Political Prisoners.

They agreed on a document denouncing the consequences of the policy of
prisoner dispersal and demanding the Spanish and French governments
recognize the representatives of the political prisoners and engage with
them so that the Basque Political Prisoners Collective (EPPK) may take part
in the ongoing political process. They agree that supporting the prisoners'
rights is an essential step towards conflict resolution. The manifesto will
be put to public institutions as a motion.

They also made a joint call to demonstrate on Jan. 7, 2006 in Bilbo, under
the banner of "Euskal Presoak Euskal Herrira, Dagozkien Eskubideen Jabe"
(Bring the Basque Prisoners to the Basque Country, Acknowledge Their Rights)

Ibaeta Forum, we ask that, together with the broad representation of Basque
society, you support the demonstration.

union, and social organizations met at the Ibaeta University Campus in
Donostia in order to address the issue of Basque Political Prisoners.

prisoner dispersal and demanding the Spanish and French governments
recognize the representatives of the political prisoners and engage with
them so that the Basque Political Prisoners Collective (EPPK) may take part

be put to public institutions as a motion.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3950
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-01-05 09:58:45
Subject:2006: Together we can Tear down the Walls
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.prolibertadweb.com
ProLibertad@...
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

Download the ProLibertad Newsletter, El Coqui Libre January 2006 edition:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclJanuary2006.pdf
_______________________________________________________________________________

2006: Together We Can Tear Down The Walls
by Benjamin Ramos, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Every year, it�s my task to write a piece for El Coqui Libre that 
encapsulates the work that the campaign did in the previous year, in hopes 
that our readership will be so impressed and inspired by our work that they 
will drop everything they�re doing, contact us and start working with our 
campaign. So far, this approach has not worked.

Albert Einstein once defined insanity as, �doing the same thing over and 
over again and expecting different results.� This year, I am not going to 
bother to list our accomplishments, speaking engagements and all the other 
assorted activities we were a part of in the year 2005. This year, I am 
going to be frank with our readership, maybe the honest approach will change 
matters.

We need you!! Plain and simple!! The movement to free our political 
prisoners is extremely small and is barely a part of the independentista 
agenda. Our movement is not growing, is not evolving and desperately needs 
revitalization. That is the truth; it hurts to admit it and write it, but 
that is what it is and once once we all accept this harsh truth, then maybe 
we can move towards resolution and change.

In the 11 years we have existed, ProLibertad has done amazing work. We, the 
few, proud and brave, have done everything we can to bring this issue to 
everyone and anyone. We have had some incredible successes and some 
failures; along the way we have jumped over hurdles and pioneered a method 
of work that others are still emulating.

We have tried to adapt our strategies and tactics to the changing world 
around us; we have tried to stay current and on top of pertinent political 
issues,. We have done our best to inspire and educate. Why is this not 
enough? What are we missing? Why aren�t you working with us? What the hell 
is the problem?

Yes, I am frustrated!! I am the classic academic overachiever who cannot 
deal with not knowing the answer!! I hate to ask this, but could you tell me 
the answer? Could you let me know what it is that we are doing that is not 
working? I have wracked my brains on this issue; I keep trying to solve 
these questions myself and it isn�t working.

I have confronted people, in a non-confrontation manner of course, about 
this issue and have asked what they think. I have heard everything from, 
�The Prisoners aren�t an issue any more since 1999!!� to, �Political 
Prisoner work is not important to people, because it has nothing to do with 
their lives.� I have even heard some folks say, �The Political prisoner 
movement is full of old people and youth don�t feel they have a space��

Do these statements represent the majority opinion? I hope not!!

The Presidential Clemency of 1999 was an amazing peoples� victory, but check 
out the back of this newsletter, there are still people in jail for fighting 
for self-determination and independence. The work is not over. The fact that 
some of the prisoners did not accept the clemency offer or were not offered 
it at all doesn�t mean that they will never be freed. Come on folks!! Why do 
we walk away from a great partial victory as though there is nothing left to 
do?

This work is effective when the people involved are patient, consistent and 
resilient. It took 25 years to free Lolita Lebron, Rafael Cancel Miranda, 
Andres Figuerora Cordero, Oscar Collazo and Irving Flores (the five 
Nationalists)!! No, this work isn�t about protesting and chanting all day!! 
No, it isn�t about constant press junkets, cameras flashing and movie stars; 
it is about maneuvering through all different areas of society. One minute 
we are speaking over a bullhorn at a picket, the next we are meeting with a 
Council person, the next we are in a classroom or at the United Nations.

Now, I would like to address the statement about how the existence of 
political prisoners has nothing to do with peoples� lives. If you simply 
take a superficial look at his issue, sure it has nothing to do with �real� 
life. Minimum wage is the same, people are still struggling and youth are 
still being railroaded from school the military industrial complex. It�s 
true, fighting to free these people isn�t going to feed the hungry or house 
the homeless. Or does it? If you take the time out to look at the bigger 
picture of this work, then the view changes.

The Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, as with many other Political 
Prisoners, were incarcerated because they were a threat to the U.S. colonial 
status quo. They fought for self-termination and independence against a 
country that imposed itself on Puerto Rico. Under International law, the 
prisoners� actions were justified. The U.S. refuses to recognize anyone who 
calls themselves a political prisoner, because the U.S. has never 
incarcerated anyone for having a different political perspectives than the 
norm. We all know this to be false.

In the past few decades this country has not only violated the civil and 
human rights of its citizenry, but has.. incarcerated, primarily through 
false pretenses, people who fight for justice and freedom. Interesting 
right? Especially, since this country was founded by people demanding an end 
to repression.

Once we get people to realize that the minute one of us loses our civil and 
human rights, it is an attack on all of us; the better off we all will be. 
When people realize that you are allowed to be �free�, as long as you don�t 
have a �dissident opinion.�, then maybe those people will see that this work 
won�t increase your hourly wage, but it will protect you and support you 
when you get out there to protest that same cheap hourly wage and are 
arrested.

This work uncovers and puts under a spot light the abuses this so-called, 
�democracy� has done against its citizenry. This work proves the belief that 
we live in a free society is false and hypocritical. The freedom of our 
political prisoners will allow to further expose this country for lying, 
cheating and imperialist monster it is. The minute we get people thinking 
that all of this has to change, then we have the foundation of a mass 
movement.

�The Political prisoner movement is full of old people and youth don�t feel 
they have a space�� As a young person, I have felt that way in the past. In 
an ideal world, all of us would naturally create a multi-generational 
movement that works together and is all inclusive. Well, that doesn�t exist 
and won�t, until you get involved! I came into this work with few skills and 
some basic political formation, and I thought there was no niche for me. So 
I carved it out. I chose to carve it out within the campaign; I could have 
easily decided to create a youth campaign or just left the work entirely, 
but it was too important to me. If you see that in ProLibertad, then join us 
and change it. Our prisoners need us active and organizing, not sitting at 
home watching MTV and playing XBOX complaining , �I don�t feel included!!�

Come on!! The youth organizing history of this country has taught us many 
lessons. One of them is that young people have always been a part of this 
work, because they made themselves a part of it. No one opened any doors, 
most of the time they knocked the doors down and walked into the work. 
Please feel free to knock down some of the doors folks, because we need you.

Look mi gente, I am getting tired and I think I have rambled... enough for 
the small pace allocated for this piece. I want to encourage people to 
dialogue and debate. As ProLibertad�s resident webmaster, I am going to 
bring this issue to the people via our web blog so that I can hear from you. 
I need you changes.

The Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, as with many other Political 
Prisoners, were incarcerated because they were a threat to the U.S. colonial 
status quo. They fought for self-termination and independence against a 
country that imposed itself on Puerto Rico. Under International law, the 
prisoners� actions were justified. The U.S. refuses to recognize anyone who 
calls themselves a political prisoner, because the U.S. has never 
incarcerated anyone for having a different political perspectives than the 
norm. We all know this to be false.

In the past few decades this country has not only violated the civil and 
human rights of its citizenry, but has.. incarcerated, primarily through 
false pretenses, people who fight for justice and freedom. Interesting 
right? Especially, since this country was founded by people demanding an end 
to repression.

Once we get people to realize that the minute one of us loses our civil and 
human rights, it is an attack on all of us; the better off we all will be. 
When people realize that you are allowed to be �free�, as long as you don�t 
have a �dissident opinion.�, then maybe those people will see that this work 
won�t increase your hourly wage, but it will protect you and support you 
when you get out there to protest that same cheap hourly wage and are 
arrested.

This work uncovers and puts under a spot light the abuses this so-called, 
�democracy� has done against its citizenry. This work proves the belief that 
we live in a free society is false and hypocritical. The freedom of our 
political prisoners will allow to further expose this country for lying, 
cheating and imperialist monster it is. The minute we get people thinking 
that all of this has to change, then we have the foundation of a mass 
movement.

�The Political prisoner movement is full of old people and youth don�t feel 
they have a space�� As a young person, I have felt that way in the past. In 
an ideal world, all of us would naturally create a multi-generational 
movement that works together and is all inclusive. Well, that doesn�t exist 
and won�t, until you get involved! I came into this work with few skills and 
some basic political formation, and I thought there was no niche for me. So 
I carved it out. I chose to carve it out within the campaign; I could have 
easily decided to create a youth campaign or just left the work entirely, 
but it was too important to me. If you see that in ProLibertad, then join us 
and change it. Our prisoners need us active and organizing, not sitting at 
home watching MTV and playing XBOX complaining , �I don�t feel included!!�

Come on!! The youth organizing history of this country has taught us many 
lessons. One of them is that young people have always been a part of this 
work, because they made themselves a part of it. No one opened any doors, 
most of the time they knocked the doors down and walked into the work. 
Please feel free to knock down some of the doors folks, because we need you.

Look mi gente, I am getting tired and I think I have rambled... enough for 
the small pace allocated for this piece. I want to encourage people to 
dialogue and debate. As ProLibertad�s resident webmaster, I am going to 
bring this issue to the people via our web blog so that I can hear from you. 
I need you to read this article and answer some of my questions, give your 
opinion on this piece, and share your thoughts on what we can do to change 
and improve this movement.

The title of this piece is, �2006: Together we can Tear down the walls.� I 
need you all to take this seriously. If we can start communicating, then 
maybe we can tear down the feelings of alienation some might feel, we could 
tear down the political differences and maybe start building the mass 
movement we need for our prisoners and Puerto Rico.

I have faith in us; our history has shown us to be a powerful liberating 
force. We have accomplished amazing things, but that has only happened when 
people have united and worked together. It all starts with talking and, 
nowadays, emailing.

I don�t know what is keeping us a part, so tell me. Be brave about yours and 
bring it out to the table. We need this folks. We have five people in jail 
and they desperately need us to continue on for them while they are away. 
Start the dialogue and begin the revolution from within. Be the change you 
want to see.

I am out of inspiring words to write!! Just let me know what you think!! 
RESPOND!!

http://www.prolibertadweb.com/ProLibFreedomBlog/





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:3951
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-01-05 10:03:17
Subject:2006: Together We Can Tear Down The Walls
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.prolibertadweb.com
ProLibertad@...
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________________

Download the ProLibertad Newsletter, El Coqui Libre January 2006 edition:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclJanuary2006.pdf
_______________________________________________________________________________

2006: Together We Can Tear Down The Walls
by Benjamin Ramos, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

Every year, it�s my task to write a piece for El Coqui Libre that
encapsulates the work that the campaign did in the previous year, in hopes
that our readership will be so impressed and inspired by our work that they
will drop everything they�re doing, contact us and start working with our
campaign. So far, this approach has not worked.

Albert Einstein once defined insanity as, �doing the same thing over and
over again and expecting different results.� This year, I am not going to
bother to list our accomplishments, speaking engagements and all the other
assorted activities we were a part of in the year 2005. This year, I am
going to be frank with our readership, maybe the honest approach will change
matters.

We need you!! Plain and simple!! The movement to free our political
prisoners is extremely small and is barely a part of the independentista
agenda. Our movement is not growing, is not evolving and desperately needs
revitalization. That is the truth; it hurts to admit it and write it, but
that is what it is and once once we all accept this harsh truth, then maybe
we can move towards resolution and change.

In the 11 years we have existed, ProLibertad has done amazing work. We, the
few, proud and brave, have done everything we can to bring this issue to
everyone and anyone. We have had some incredible successes and some
failures; along the way we have jumped over hurdles and pioneered a method
of work that others are still emulating.

We have tried to adapt our strategies and tactics to the changing world
around us; we have tried to stay current and on top of pertinent political
issues,. We have done our best to inspire and educate. Why is this not
enough? What are we missing? Why aren�t you working with us? What the hell
is the problem?

Yes, I am frustrated!! I am the classic academic overachiever who cannot
deal with not knowing the answer!! I hate to ask this, but could you tell me
the answer? Could you let me know what it is that we are doing that is not
working? I have wracked my brains on this issue; I keep trying to solve
these questions myself and it isn�t working.

I have confronted people, in a non-confrontation manner of course, about
this issue and have asked what they think. I have heard everything from,
�The Prisoners aren�t an issue any more since 1999!!� to, �Political
Prisoner work is not important to people, because it has nothing to do with
their lives.� I have even heard some folks say, �The Political prisoner
movement is full of old people and youth don�t feel they have a space��

Do these statements represent the majority opinion? I hope not!!

The Presidential Clemency of 1999 was an amazing peoples� victory, but check
out the back of this newsletter, there are still people in jail for fighting
for self-determination and independence. The work is not over. The fact that
some of the prisoners did not accept the clemency offer or were not offered
it at all doesn�t mean that they will never be freed. Come on folks!! Why do
we walk away from a great partial victory as though there is nothing left to
do?

This work is effective when the people involved are patient, consistent and
resilient. It took 25 years to free Lolita Lebron, Rafael Cancel Miranda,
Andres Figuerora Cordero, Oscar Collazo and Irving Flores (the five
Nationalists)!! No, this work isn�t about protesting and chanting all day!!
No, it isn�t about constant press junkets, cameras flashing and movie stars;
it is about maneuvering through all different areas of society. One minute
we are speaking over a bullhorn at a picket, the next we are meeting with a
Council person, the next we are in a classroom or at the United Nations.

Now, I would like to address the statement about how the existence of
political prisoners has nothing to do with peoples� lives. If you simply
take a superficial look at his issue, sure it has nothing to do with �real�
life. Minimum wage is the same, people are still struggling and youth are
still being railroaded from school the military industrial complex. It�s
true, fighting to free these people isn�t going to feed the hungry or house
the homeless. Or does it? If you take the time out to look at the bigger
picture of this work, then the view changes.

The Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, as with many other Political
Prisoners, were incarcerated because they were a threat to the U.S. colonial
status quo. They fought for self-termination and independence against a
country that imposed itself on Puerto Rico. Under International law, the
prisoners� actions were justified. The U.S. refuses to recognize anyone who
calls themselves a political prisoner, because the U.S. has never
incarcerated anyone for having a different political perspectives than the
norm. We all know this to be false.

In the past few decades this country has not only violated the civil and
human rights of its citizenry, but has.. incarcerated, primarily through
false pretenses, people who fight for justice and freedom. Interesting
right? Especially, since this country was founded by people demanding an end
to repression.

Once we get people to realize that the minute one of us loses our civil and
human rights, it is an attack on all of us; the better off we all will be.
When people realize that you are allowed to be �free�, as long as you don�t
have a �dissident opinion.�, then maybe those people will see that this work
won�t increase your hourly wage, but it will protect you and support you
when you get out there to protest that same cheap hourly wage and are
arrested.

This work uncovers and puts under a spot light the abuses this so-called,
�democracy� has done against its citizenry. This work proves the belief that
we live in a free society is false and hypocritical. The freedom of our
political prisoners will allow to further expose this country for lying,
cheating and imperialist monster it is. The minute we get people thinking
that all of this has to change, then we have the foundation of a mass
movement.

�The Political prisoner movement is full of old people and youth don�t feel
they have a space�� As a young person, I have felt that way in the past. In
an ideal world, all of us would naturally create a multi-generational
movement that works together and is all inclusive. Well, that doesn�t exist
and won�t, until you get involved! I came into this work with few skills and
some basic political formation, and I thought there was no niche for me. So
I carved it out. I chose to carve it out within the campaign; I could have
easily decided to create a youth campaign or just left the work entirely,
but it was too important to me. If you see that in ProLibertad, then join us
and change it. Our prisoners need us active and organizing, not sitting at
home watching MTV and playing XBOX complaining , �I don�t feel included!!�

Come on!! The youth organizing history of this country has taught us many
lessons. One of them is that young people have always been a part of this
work, because they made themselves a part of it. No one opened any doors,
most of the time they knocked the doors down and walked into the work.
Please feel free to knock down some of the doors folks, because we need you.

Look mi gente, I am getting tired and I think I have rambled... enough for
the small pace allocated for this piece. I want to encourage people to
dialogue and debate. As ProLibertad�s resident webmaster, I am going to
bring this issue to the people via our web blog so that I can hear from you.
I need you changes.

The Puerto Rican Political Prisoners, as with many other Political
Prisoners, were incarcerated because they were a threat to the U.S. colonial
status quo. They fought for self-termination and independence against a
country that imposed itself on Puerto Rico. Under International law, the
prisoners� actions were justified. The U.S. refuses to recognize anyone who
calls themselves a political prisoner, because the U.S. has never
incarcerated anyone for having a different political perspectives than the
norm. We all know this to be false.

In the past few decades this country has not only violated the civil and
human rights of its citizenry, but has.. incarcerated, primarily through
false pretenses, people who fight for justice and freedom. Interesting
right? Especially, since this country was founded by people demanding an end
to repression.

Once we get people to realize that the minute one of us loses our civil and
human rights, it is an attack on all of us; the better off we all will be.
When people realize that you are allowed to be �free�, as long as you don�t
have a �dissident opinion.�, then maybe those people will see that this work
won�t increase your hourly wage, but it will protect you and support you
when you get out there to protest that same cheap hourly wage and are
arrested.

This work uncovers and puts under a spot light the abuses this so-called,
�democracy� has done against its citizenry. This work proves the belief that
we live in a free society is false and hypocritical. The freedom of our
political prisoners will allow to further expose this country for lying,
cheating and imperialist monster it is. The minute we get people thinking
that all of this has to change, then we have the foundation of a mass
movement.

�The Political prisoner movement is full of old people and youth don�t feel
they have a space�� As a young person, I have felt that way in the past. In
an ideal world, all of us would naturally create a multi-generational
movement that works together and is all inclusive. Well, that doesn�t exist
and won�t, until you get involved! I came into this work with few skills and
some basic political formation, and I thought there was no niche for me. So
I carved it out. I chose to carve it out within the campaign; I could have
easily decided to create a youth campaign or just left the work entirely,
but it was too important to me. If you see that in ProLibertad, then join us
and change it. Our prisoners need us active and organizing, not sitting at
home watching MTV and playing XBOX complaining , �I don�t feel included!!�

Come on!! The youth organizing history of this country has taught us many
lessons. One of them is that young people have always been a part of this
work, because they made themselves a part of it. No one opened any doors,
most of the time they knocked the doors down and walked into the work.
Please feel free to knock down some of the doors folks, because we need you.

Look mi gente, I am getting tired and I think I have rambled... enough for
the small pace allocated for this piece. I want to encourage people to
dialogue and debate. As ProLibertad�s resident webmaster, I am going to
bring this issue to the people via our web blog so that I can hear from you.
I need you to read this article and answer some of my questions, give your
opinion on this piece, and share your thoughts on what we can do to change
and improve this movement.

The title of this piece is, �2006: Together we can Tear down the walls.� I
need you all to take this seriously. If we can start communicating, then
maybe we can tear down the feelings of alienation some might feel, we could
tear down the political differences and maybe start building the mass
movement we need for our prisoners and Puerto Rico.

I have faith in us; our history has shown us to be a powerful liberating
force. We have accomplished amazing things, but that has only happened when
people have united and worked together. It all starts with talking and,
nowadays, emailing.

I don�t know what is keeping us a part, so tell me. Be brave about yours and
bring it out to the table. We need this folks. We have five people in jail
and they desperately need us to continue on for them while they are away.
Start the dialogue and begin the revolution from within. Be the change you
want to see.

I am out of inspiring words to write!! Just let me know what you think!!
RESPOND!!

http://www.prolibertadweb.com/ProLibFreedomBlog/

******************************************************************************
To update all supporters, The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
has a new Project email addrerss, so please update your address books:
freethecubanfive@...

Download our January 2006 newsletter: 
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5January2006.pdf

******************************************************************************

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition

Post ID:3957
Sender:"Freethe5 Libertadparalos5" <freethecubanFIVE@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-01-10 11:10:05
Subject:Join the Venceremos Brigade
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
FreethecubanFIVE@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

******************************************************************************
To update all supporters, The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
has a new Project email addrerss, so please update your address books:
freethecubanfive@...

Download our January 2006 newsletter:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5January2006.pdf

******************************************************************************

Join the 37th Contingent of the Venceremos Brigade!!!
Applications now available for July 2-17, 2006, work brigade to Cuba!!

Now is your opportunity to join the Venceremos Brigade's travel challenge, 
to see Cuba, and to defend your constitutional right to travel.

Since 1969, over 8,000 Brigadistas have traveled to Cuba to see the Cuban 
revolution for themselves and to take a stand against the unjust and immoral 
U.S. policy towards our neighbor.

Over the years, Brigadistas have harvested sugar cane, citrus, and corn, 
built housing, painted and repaired buildings - working side by side with 
Cuban workers and students. At the same time, we meet with leaders of Cuba's 
federations, mass organizations,and with artists, teachers, social workers, 
and Cuban 'internationalists' (people who have served abroad, fighting 
apartheid in Southern Africa or fighting disease throughout the world) and 
many others. Our goal is to see and learn as much as possible and hear from 
as many voices as we can. It is truly a life-changing experience.

The Venceremos Brigade has never requested a license from the U.S. 
government to travel to Cuba. We believe it is our Constitutional right to 
travel where we please. While the vast majority of the U.S. public supports 
an end to the travel restrictions, the Bush Administration has increased 
harassment of Cuban travelers and has eliminated almost all possibilities 
for legal travel. In response, the VB has organized extremely successful 
public travel challenges since 2002.

Many Brigadistas have received letters from the Department of the Treasury 
demanding information and threatening fines. The government is reacting to 
our challenge and we will continue to fight legally and politically - and 
collectively - to resist these threats and to end the restrictions.

This is why we need more people than ever to participate in the 37th 
Contingent, our 4th annual Travel Challenge.

Here is your chance to be on the cutting edge of the movement to end the 
U.S. restrictions on travel to Cuba and to see Revolutionary Cuba with your 
own eyes - If we don't stand up for our constitutional rights, who will?

This year we will be traveling to Cuba July 2-17, 2006, crossing the bridge 
into Buffalo, New York, on July 17th. The VB will visit both the eastern and 
western parts of the island, staying in a school near Santiago and in Havana 
province at our international work camp. All Venceremos Brigade travel 
challengers attend legal and other preparation sessions prior to the trip. 
Contact us for more information and an application.

vbrigade@...
www.venceremosbrigade.org
voice mail: 212-560-4360


Venceremos Brigade
PO Box 5202
Englewood, NJ 07631-5202
email: vbrigade@...
voicemail: 212-560-4360
website: www.venceremosbrigade.org

_________________________________________________________________

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

This Digest contains several important announcements:

1.  Despierta Boricua segment for Fri. Jan. 13th, 2006
2.  Juan mari Bras documentary on Sat. Jan. 14th, 2006
3.  Tribute Dinner for Political prisoners on Sun. Jan. 15th, 2006
4.  Assata/Cuban5/Filiberto Ojeda Event on Fri. Jan. 20th, 2006

_______________________________________________________________________________

Despierta Boricua is a fifteen minute Radio segment produced for WBAI 99.5 
FM Friday Morning Wake UP Call by The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign.  
Despierta Boricua airs at 6:45am every week, but is subject to re-scheduling 
depending on the Station�s needs.

This week's segment (Fri. Jan. 13th) will feature an interview with Roberto 
Rabin of el Comite Pro-Rescate y Desarollo De Vieques and the work they are 
doing to decontaminate Vieques.

You can listen via webstream at: http://www.wbai.org and if you miss the 
segment go to the WBAI website and go to the Archives section.
_______________________________________________________________________________

A new documentary is being screened this Saturday about Juan Mari Bras

The Malcolm X Commemoration Committee   Proudly presents

Its Tenth Annual Dinner Tribute  To the Families of Our Political Prisoners  
& Prisoners of War

This Year's Theme: No Surrender! No Retreat!

With Special Guests
Baba James Small
Esperanza Martell
Dr. James McIntosh
& more!

Sunday, January 15, 2006
Bed-Stuy Restoration Plaza
1368 Fulton Street, Brooklyn
3-7 PM . Tickets $35.00*

For more information, please call 718-949-5153

*ALL PROCEEDS GO TO THE COMMISSARY
OF THE FREEDOM FIGHTERS
REPRESENTED AT THE DINNER

Dinner will be served from 3pm to 4 pm.
Program begins promptly at 4:15

THE MALCOLM X COMMEMORATION COMMITTEE
P.O. BOX 340084
JAMAICA, NEW YORK 11434

Malcolmites Host Annual
Political Prisoner Dinner Tribute

On Sunday, January 15th, the Malcolm X Commemoration Committee will host its 
annual dinner tribute to "the families of our political prisoners." This 
enormous tribute will take place at the Bed-Stuy Restoration Plaza, 1368 
Fulton Street, in Brooklyn.

The program is from 3-7p.m.

For more than ten years now, the Malcolm X Commemoration Committee (MXCC) 
has hosted this tribute in addition to its other work in defense of the 
revolutionary legacy of Malcolm X. The proceeds from the dinner go directly 
into the commissary account for each political prisoner who is represented 
by his family. The program focuses on freedom fighters who have family in 
this metropolitan area.

Sundiata Acoli, Herman Bell, The Move 9, Mumia Abu-Jamal, Bashir Hameed, 
Abdul-Majied, and Marshall
Eddie Conway , Russell Shoatz, Mutulu Shakur and Robert Seth Hayes have been 
proudly represented by their families at this annual event.

The Malcolm X Commemoration Committee has always insisted that Black 
political prisoners, all targets of the FBI CounterIntelligence Program, are 
the hidden legacy of Malcolm X. Just as important, there is also the untold 
story of how their wrongful incarceration has impacted on their families and 
their communities.

Even though many of our political prisoners are now going into their fourth 
decade of wrongful incarceration, they continue to hold firm to their 
beliefs in the righteousness of our struggle. Hence, this year's
theme is 'No Surrender! No Retreat!'

"Last year, we went to Albany to get our legislators to understand that it 
is way past time for them to move to get our freedom fighters out," 
explained an angry Herman Ferguson, Chairman for the MXCC and himself a 
former political prisoner. "This year, since they obviously haven't gotten 
the message, we will have to step up our campaign for parole reform and 
recognition of the status of political prisoners. We will move our efforts 
up another notch.

In addition to a sumptuous dinner. this year's event will feature guest 
presentations by Baba James Small,  Esperanza Martell and Dr. James 
McIntosh. Baba James Small was in the Organization of Afro-American Unity 
responsible for the security of Ella Little-Collins, Malcolm's powerful 
"big" sister. For nearly forty years now, in keeping with Sis. Ella's vision 
and initiative, he has organized and maintained the annual pilgrimage to 
Malcolm's gravesite. Esperanza Martell is one the chief players responsible 
for Pro-Libertad's successful amnesty campaign for eleven of Puerto Rico's 
political prisoners. Dr. James McIntosh, co-chair of CEMOTAP (the Committee 
to Eliminate Media Offensive To Afrikan People), has emerged as one of Black 
New York's premiere human rights voices.

Tickets for this special event are $35.00 and can be purchased in advance.

For more information, please call 718-949-5153.
_______________________________________________________________________________

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary�s Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition

_____________________________________________________________________________

Download the ProLibertad Newsletter, El Coqui Libre January 2006 edition:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclJanuary2006.pdf
_____________________________________________________________________________

This Digest contains several important announcements:

1.  Despierta Boricua segment for Fri. Jan. 13th, 2006
2.  Juan mari Bras documentary on Sat. Jan. 14th, 2006
3.  Tribute Dinner for Political prisoners on Sun. Jan. 15th, 2006
4.  Assata/Cuban5/Filiberto Ojeda Event on Fri. Jan. 20th, 2006

_______________________________________________________________________________

Despierta Boricua is a fifteen minute Radio segment produced for WBAI 99.5 
FM Friday Morning Wake UP Call by The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign.  
Despierta Boricua airs at 6:45am every week, but is subject to re-scheduling 
depending on the Station�s needs.

This week's segment (Fri. Jan. 13th) will feature an interview with Roberto 
Rabin of el Comite Pro-Rescate y Desarollo De Vieques and the work they are 
doing to decontaminate Vieques.

You can listen via webstream at: http://www.wbai.org and if you miss the 
segment go to the WBAI website and go to the Archives section.
_______________________________________________________________________________

A new documentary is being screened this Saturday about Juan Mari Bras

HOSTOS COMMUNITY COLLEGE
149 & GRAN CONCOURSE

Film: 7:00-9:00 pm

& Prisoners of War

Post ID:3965
Sender:"Freethe5 Libertadparalos5" <freethecubanFIVE@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-01-14 13:28:23
Subject:Cuban 5/Go to Cuba Summer 2006!!
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
FreethecubanFIVE@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

******************************************************************************
To update all supporters, The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
has a new Project email addrerss, so please update your address books:
freethecubanfive@...

Download our January 2006 newsletter:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5January2006.pdf

******************************************************************************

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary's Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition

******************************************************************************

Join the 37th Contingent of the Venceremos Brigade!!!
Applications now available for July 2-17, 2006, work brigade to Cuba!!

Now is your opportunity to join the Venceremos Brigade's travel challenge,
to see Cuba, and to defend your constitutional right to travel.

Since 1969, over 8,000 Brigadistas have traveled to Cuba to see the Cuban
revolution for themselves and to take a stand against the unjust and immoral
U.S. policy towards our neighbor.

Over the years, Brigadistas have harvested sugar cane, citrus, and corn,
built housing, painted and repaired buildings - working side by side with
Cuban workers and students. At the same time, we meet with leaders of Cuba's
federations, mass organizations,and with artists, teachers, social workers,
and Cuban 'internationalists' (people who have served abroad, fighting
apartheid in Southern Africa or fighting disease throughout the world) and
many others. Our goal is to see and learn as much as possible and hear from
as many voices as we can. It is truly a life-changing experience.

The Venceremos Brigade has never requested a license from the U.S.
government to travel to Cuba. We believe it is our Constitutional right to
travel where we please. While the vast majority of the U.S. public supports
an end to the travel restrictions, the Bush Administration has increased
harassment of Cuban travelers and has eliminated almost all possibilities
for legal travel. In response, the VB has organized extremely successful
public travel challenges since 2002.

Many Brigadistas have received letters from the Department of the Treasury
demanding information and threatening fines. The government is reacting to
our challenge and we will continue to fight legally and politically - and
collectively - to resist these threats and to end the restrictions.

This is why we need more people than ever to participate in the 37th
Contingent, our 4th annual Travel Challenge.

Here is your chance to be on the cutting edge of the movement to end the
U.S. restrictions on travel to Cuba and to see Revolutionary Cuba with your
own eyes - If we don't stand up for our constitutional rights, who will?

This year we will be traveling to Cuba July 2-17, 2006, crossing the bridge
into Buffalo, New York, on July 17th. The VB will visit both the eastern and
western parts of the island, staying in a school near Santiago and in Havana
province at our international work camp. All Venceremos Brigade travel
challengers attend legal and other preparation sessions prior to the trip.
Contact us for more information and an application.

vbrigade@...
www.venceremosbrigade.org
voice mail: 212-560-4360

Venceremos Brigade
PO Box 5202
Englewood, NJ 07631-5202
email: vbrigade@...
voicemail: 212-560-4360
website: www.venceremosbrigade.org

_________________________________________________________________

http://search.msn.click-url.com/go/onm00200636ave/direct/01/

This is why we need more people than ever to participate in the 37th
Contingent, our 4th annual Travel Challenge.

Here is your chance to be on the cutting edge of the movement to end the
U.S. restrictions on travel to Cuba and to see Revolutionary Cuba with your

This year we will be traveling to Cuba July 2-17, 2006, crossing the bridge
into Buffalo, New York, on July 17th. The VB will visit both the eastern and

******************************************************************************

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary's Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition

******************************************************************************

Join the 37th Contingent of the Venceremos Brigade!!!
Applications now available for July 2-17, 2006, work brigade to Cuba!!

Now is your opportunity to join the Venceremos Brigade's travel challenge,
to see Cuba, and to defend your constitutional right to travel.

Since 1969, over 8,000 Brigadistas have traveled to Cuba to see the Cuban
revolution for themselves and to take a stand against the unjust and immoral
U.S. policy towards our neighbor.

Over the years, Brigadistas have harvested sugar cane, citrus, and corn,
built housing, painted and repaired buildings - working side by side with
Cuban workers and students. At the same time, we meet with leaders of Cuba's
federations, mass organizations,and with artists, teachers, social workers,
and Cuban 'internationalists' (people who have served abroad, fighting
apartheid in Southern Africa or fighting disease throughout the world) and
many others. Our goal is to see and learn as much as possible and hear from
as many voices as we can. It is truly a life-changing experience.

The Venceremos Brigade has never requested a license from the U.S.
government to travel to Cuba. We believe it is our Constitutional right to
travel where we please. While the vast majority of the U.S. public supports
an end to the travel restrictions, the Bush Administration has increased
harassment of Cuban travelers and has eliminated almost all possibilities
for legal travel. In response, the VB has organized extremely successful
public travel challenges since 2002.

Many Brigadistas have received letters from the Department of the Treasury
demanding information and threatening fines. The government is reacting to
our challenge and we will continue to fight legally and politically - and
collectively - to resist these threats and to end the restrictions.

This is why we need more people than ever to participate in the 37th
Contingent, our 4th annual Travel Challenge.

Here is your chance to be on the cutting edge of the movement to end the
U.S. restrictions on travel to Cuba and to see Revolutionary Cuba with your
own eyes - If we don't stand up for our constitutional rights, who will?

This year we will be traveling to Cuba July 2-17, 2006, crossing the bridge
into Buffalo, New York, on July 17th. The VB will visit both the eastern and
western parts of the island, staying in a school near Santiago and in Havana
province at our international work camp. All Venceremos Brigade travel
challengers attend legal and other preparation sessions prior to the trip.
Contact us for more information and an application.

vbrigade@...
www.venceremosbrigade.org
voice mail: 212-560-4360

Venceremos Brigade
PO Box 5202
Englewood, NJ 07631-5202
email: vbrigade@...
voicemail: 212-560-4360
website: www.venceremosbrigade.org

Post ID:3976
Sender:"Freethe5 Libertadparalos5" <freethecubanFIVE@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-01-19 21:06:27
Subject:Cuban 5 event/Update on the CASE
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
FreethecubanFIVE@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

******************************************************************************
To update all supporters, The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
has a new Project email addrerss, so please update your address books:
freethecubanfive@...

Download our January 2006 newsletter:
http://www.freethecuban5.com/JF5January2006.pdf

******************************************************************************

ASSATA SHAKUR, THE CUBAN 5 AND FILIBERTO OJEDA RIOS: State Repression and
Terrorism

Friday January 20th, 2006 at 7pm St. Mary's Episcopal Church 521 W126th St.
(btwn. Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway)
Take the 1 or 9 train to W125th St. and Broadway

As the U.S. government continues its terrorist and repressive occupation of
Iraq, it has also waged a war against freedom fighters and revolutionaries
in the U.S.

In the past year, the U.S. government has increased the bounty on Assata
Shakur and added her name to the domestic terrorist list, has intervened in
the case of the Cuban 5 in order to undo the decision of the 11th Circuit
Court for a retrial, and masterminded the political assassination of Puerto
Rican revolutionary leader Filiberto Ojeda Rios!!

Join The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, Hands off Assata
Coalition and the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign for a night of discussion and
dialogue about U.S. terrorism and repression in our communities.

Program:
Benjamin Ramos, Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
Frank Velgara, The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
Desiree Gordon, Hands off Assata Coalition

*******************************************************************************

The Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta has ruled against the U.S. 
government in accepting, on January 6, two amicus briefs (friends of the 
court documents presented in support of one side) by the National Lawyers 
Guild, the Florida branch of the National Association of Criminal Defense 
Lawyers, and the National Association of Federal Public Defenders, presented 
in favor of five Cubans imprisoned in the United States.

The U.S. Attorney had motioned the court to reject the two amicus briefs 
alleging that they did not offer a different perspective than that presented 
by the defense attorneys of the Five, and was a means by which to avoid the 
limited number of pages imposed on the defense in its petition to the court. 
However, on January 13, in a motion of response to the court, the U.S. 
Attorney also included an amicus brief by the Cuban-American Bar Association 
supporting its arguments. The court has yet to pronounce on this.

The U.S. Attorney's motion to reject the defense amicus briefs was a 
surprise to the legal community by virtue of the fact that it was extremely 
unusual. It provoked a strong reaction from criminal defense attorneys who 
referred to the protection offered by the Sixth Amendment in relation to 
race, ideology, religious, ethnic and other irrational prejudices.

The National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, its Florida branch and 
the National Association of Federal Public Defenders argued in their joint 
amicus that the accused should be able to count on Constitutional guarantees 
for a fair trial.

The importance of this resides in the fact that National Association of 
Criminal Defense Lawyers is the only organization of its kind in Miami-Dade 
County.

For its part, the National Lawyers Guild presented its amicus on the right 
to a fair trial and the right to due process � both established by the Sixth 
Amendment - and emphasized the error of the Florida court in not authorizing 
a change of trial location as well as the inappropriate conduct of the 
prosecution during the trial.

Once accepted by the appeals court, the two amicus now become part of the 
case file it will review. According to procedures established by the Atlanta 
court, on December 15 the defense attorneys presented documents 
corresponding to questions asked by the court. The U.S. Attorney presented 
arguments on January 13, and now the defense can respond to the latter on 
January 27. During the week of February 13, a day will be held for an oral 
presentation by both the defense and the prosecution, designed to respond to 
any concerns or questions the 12 judges may have.

In recent comments on the legal process against the Cuban Five, the 
President of the Cuban National Assembly, Ricardo Alarc�n, underlined the 
violations that had begun from the very day of the arrest of the five men in 
1998, saying "that there should never have been a trial, let alone an 
arrest" and pointed out violations of the Fifth, Sixth and Eighth Amendments 
of the U.S. Constitution.  "In the case of the Cuban Five, the fight should 
go beyond obtaining a new trial for them, but be a battle for their 
immediate release, so they not remain in prison one more day". Alarc�n drew 
attention to the decision by the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary 
Detentions, which in May of last year � after two years of analysis of the 
case � determined that the trial had been illegal. Following this on August 
9, a three-judge panel of the Atlanta appeals court declared null and void 
the original trial in the Miami federal court. Thus, eight important experts 
from two different forums have expressed their condemnation of the legal 
process against the Five and the illegal sentences imposed upon them.

The National Assembly President stressed the need to continue fighting to 
convert the cause of the Five into an international campaign against 
injustice, and condemn their manipulated trial, demanding their immediate 
release.

_________________________________________________________________

http://messenger.msn.click-url.com/go/onm00200471ave/direct/01/

The Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta has ruled against the U.S.

Attorney also included an amicus brief by the Cuban-American Bar Association

prosecution during the trial.

President of the Cuban National Assembly, Ricardo Alarc�n, underlined the

of the U.S. Constitution.  "In the case of the Cuban Five, the fight should

immediate release, so they not remain in prison one more day". Alarc�n drew

Detentions, which in May of last year � after two years of analysis of the
