The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601 4751
__________________________________________________________

Download the June 2006 Edition of the ProLibertad Newsletter El Coqui Libre:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclJuly2006.pdf
__________________________________________________________

PICKET FOR ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON IN PHILADELPHIA!!
Saturday August 5th at 12pm!!
FEDERAL DETENTION CENTER
700 ARCH STREET

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign received a call on Friday July 14th from 
Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho Negron; he informed us that 
he was released from the "hole" on Thursday July 13th, he is still not 
receiving his medication, he is in general population and that he is doing 
well (despite his stomach/gastrointestinal issues).

Antonio told us that he is having a hearing on Saturday August 5th!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling a demonstration in front of 
Federal Detention Center Philadelphia at 12pm on Saturday August 5th.

ProLibertad will be providing transportation from NYC to Philadelphia!!  If 
you are interested in going with us on our FREEDOM BUS (the most 
revolutionary yellow School bus ever) the contribution will be $20 per 
person (round trip).   We will be leaving on Saturday August 5th from w179th 
St. and Amsterdam Avenue at 8:30am SHARP!!

GET ON THE BUS!!  FREE ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!!  FREE THE PUERTO RICAN 
POLITICAL PRISONERS!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

PROLIBERTAD FREEDOM COOKOUT 2006!! HELP US RAISE MONEY FOR THE PUERTO RICAN
POLITICAL PRISONERS!!

Join ProLibertad on our annual Freedom Cook out to HighLands Pool in
Ringwood, New Jersey!!

Enjoy the sun, fun and relaxation of HighLands Pool!! Bring your swimming
trunks for the cool and refreshing Chemical-free mountain stream-fed pool!!
We will have DELICOUS BORICUA FOOD, FUN, MUSIC, DOMINOES, GAMES, SPORTS and
RELAXATION!!

Saturday July 22nd, 2006 at 9am!! Get on the Bus!!

Meet at the corner of w179th St. and Broadway at 9am to catch one of our
Freedom Vans to HighLand Pools!!

Transportation from NYC ($10), Entrance to HighLand Pools ($5) and Food
($5); all together $20 (Adults) $15 for (Children). TICKETS ARE AVAILABLE
VIA EMAIL ( ProLibertad@...) OR HOTLINE: 718-601-4751

Contact ProLibertad to reserve a seat on our Freedom Bus by calling the
ProLibertad hotline: 718-601-4751 or email us at : ProLibertad@...

PICKET FOR ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON IN PHILADELPHIA!!
Saturday August 5th at 12pm!!
FEDERAL DETENTION CENTER
700 ARCH STREET

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign received a call on Friday July 14th from
Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho Negron; he informed us that
he was released from the "hole" on Thursday July 13th, he is still not
receiving his medication, he is in general population and that he is doing
well (despite his stomach/gastrointestinal issues).

Antonio told us that he is having a hearing on Saturday August 5th!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling a demonstration in front of
Federal Detention Center Philadelphia at 12pm on Saturday August 5th.

ProLibertad will be providing transportation from NYC to Philadelphia!! If
you are interested in going with us on our FREEDOM BUS (the most
revolutionary yellow School bus ever) the contribution will be $20 per

Designformat designed for the way NOT to use them).  Design Patterns, 
you'll avoid

Post ID:4347

Subject:Aug. 5th-Philly Picket for Antonio Camacho Negron
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://www.ProLibertadweb.com
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601 4751
__________________________________________________________

Download the July 2006 Edition of the ProLibertad Newsletter El Coqui Libre:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/eclJuly2006.pdf
__________________________________________________________

PICKET FOR ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON IN PHILADELPHIA!!
Saturday August 5th at 12pm!!
FEDERAL DETENTION CENTER
700 ARCH STREET

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign received a call on Friday July 14th from
Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Antonio Camacho Negron; he informed us that
he was released from the "hole" on Thursday July 13th, he is still not
receiving his medication, he is in general population and that he is doing
well (despite his stomach/gastrointestinal issues).

Antonio told us that he is having a hearing on Saturday August 5th!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign is calling a demonstration in front of
Federal Detention Center Philadelphia at 12pm on Saturday August 5th.

ProLibertad will be providing transportation from NYC to Philadelphia!! If
you are interested in going with us on our FREEDOM BUS (the most
revolutionary yellow School bus ever) the contribution will be $20 per
person (round trip). We will be leaving on Saturday August 5th from w179th
St. and Amsterdam Avenue at 8:30am SHARP!!

GET ON THE BUS!! FREE ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON!! FREE THE PUERTO RICAN
POLITICAL PRISONERS!!

Post ID:4350
Sender:"Ora Friedman" <tkresge@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-07-24 14:55:09
Subject:0ver 3OO $tyles of Replica //atches!
Message:

Genuine Swiss made Rolex replicas are as close to the real thing 
as a replica watch can be. Sometimes even the professional jewelers 
are unable to tell the difference from the real Rolex watch.  
All genuine Swiss Rolex Replicas should have the following:- Full 1-year 
Warranty 
  - Solid 14k or 18k Gold on two-toned models
  - Guaranteed triple-wrapped gold on all-gold models 
  - Genuine sapphire crystal - a type of glass that is many times better 

  at resisting scratches than regular glass.
  - The color of the gold looks exactly like a genuine Rolex watch If 
the retailer does not offer this, do not purchase from them!//e have all 
this! JUST 
  COME and buy your REPLICA //atches!


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Subject:Sept. 12th-NYC Demo. for the Cuban 5
Message:

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
freethecubanfive@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751

*******************************************************************************
FREE THE CUBAN 5!! Rally and March to demand the freedom of the Cuban 5

TUESDAY SEPT. 12TH AT 4PM!!
GATHER AT TIMES SQUARE U.S. MILITARY RECRUITMENT CENTER (42nd St. and Times
Square) AND THEN MARCH TO THE DAG HAMERSKJOLD PLAZA (E47th St. and 1st Ave.)

Bring your flags, banners and noisemakers!!

On Sept. 12th, 1998, Gerardo Hernandez, Ramon Laba�ino Fernando Gonzalez,
Rene Gonzalez, and Antonio Guerrero were arrested and spent 17 months in
solidarity confinement!! They were convicted in a politically charged trial
in Miami in June 2001 for engaging in espionage and threatening national
security.

Nothing could be further from the truth!! The Cuban 5 infiltrated
Cuban-American right-wing terrorist organizations based in Miami to monitor
their actions and to protect the national sovereignty of their homeland Cuba
and to safeguard the American people from terrorist actions within the
United States.

Join us on Tuesday Sept. 12th as we demand the freedom of these innocent
men!!

Demand Visitation Rights for the Cuban 5!!

Extradite CIA Agent Luis Posada Carriles!!

For more information on the Cuban 5 Rally/March call 718-601-4751 or email
freethecubanfive@...

Fernando Gonzalez, Gerardo Hernandez, Ramon Laba�ino, Antonio Guerrero and
Rene Gonzalez, have been unjustly imprisoned in U.S. federal penitentiaries
since the fall of 1998. Their crime? Fighting terrorism.

Since 1998 their imprisonment has been determined to be arbitrary and
illegal by a unanimous decision of a five member panel of U.N. human rights
experts. Their convictions were reversed by a unanimous decision of three
judges of the Atlanta Court of Appeals. Those decisions were announced in
May 2005 and August 2005, but the Five Cubans are still in prison subjected
to cruel and unusual treatment with severe violations of their human rights,
including the denial of visas to the wives of Gerardo and Rene.

Three federal judges for 16 months examined the prejudicial and illegal
practices that characterized their trial in Miami. In their 93 page decision
they concluded unanimously that Fernando Gonzalez, Gerardo Hernandez, Ramon
Laba�ino, Antonio Guerrero and Rene Gonzalez were victims of an
unprecedented bias, which denied them their fundamental right to a fair
trial. Their ruling set aside each and every one of their convictions. It
was a great victory, but not one that Washington and its friends in Miami
could accept. Such a powerful statement by one of the highest - if not the
most conservative - courts in the United States outraged those ordinarily
unchallenged makers of Cuban policy and compelled them, in desperation, to
resort to a rarely used legal tactic to appeal the decision.

We are now awaiting word on whether or not the federal appellate court in
Atlanta will hold firm to its' initial determination.

Two months ago, Ricardo Alarcon, the President of the Cuban Parliament,
urged that a period starting September 12th and ending October 6th be used
to break down the silence surrounding the case of the Cuban Five as well as
to condemn all terrorism and demand justice for its victims.

Whether it was sending medical brigades, sending scientific experts, or
training future physicians, Cuba has always responded to the needs of the
international community. Now, it is our turn to stand in support of Cuba
and its call to Free the Cuban 5.

We call upon all of you to join in the international campaign against US
sponsored terrorism from September 12 to October the 6, 2006, by:

� Endorsing this call for a period of activities from September 12th to
October 6th of this year to educate and rally public support for the freedom
of Fernando Gonzalez, Gerardo Hernandez, Ramon Laba�ino, Antonio Guerrero
and Rene Gonzalez and to demand that their families be allowed to visit
them; ADD YOUR ORGANIZATION TO THE LIST BELOW!!

� Discuss scheduling an event in your church, school, political
organization, solidarity group, or community organization during The Free
the Five Month; we need to fill this 25 day period with activitres
throughout NYC and throughout the United States.

� Contact The Free the Cuban 5 Organizing Committee for resources, which can
help to organize your event and to coordinate with others building the
Freedom Calendar for the 5.

Please send your endorsement to: FreetheCubanfive@... and circulate
this call widely. PLEASE LET US KNOW WHEN YOU CAN SCHEDULE YOUR EVENT
BETWEEN SEPT. 12TH-OCT. 6TH, 2006

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5, IFCO/Pastors for Peace,
Casa de Las Am�ricas, Jericho New York City, The ProLibertad Freedom
Campaign, The Venceremos Brigade, Jane Franklin, Cuba Solidarity New York,

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:4378
Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>
Post Date/Time:2006-08-09 22:17:36
Subject:Aug. 5th Pictures of ProLibertad and MOVE
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://www.ProLibertadWeb.com
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
______________________________________________________________________________

The following article was sent out by the International Concened Family and 
Freinds of Mumia Abu Jamal and MOVE; ProLibertad thanks both organizations 
for their amazing solidarity and support on Saturday August 5th!! LONG LIVE 
JOHN AFRICA!!  FREE ALL POLITICAL PRISONERS!!

Please check out the pictures of August 5th:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/page21.html

On August 5, 2006 activists converged on Philadelphia to show their 
unyielding support for the MOVE 9, incarcerated Puerto Rican 
independentista, Antonio Camacho Negron, Mumia Abu-Jamal, Leonard Peltier, 
Russell "Maroon" Shoatz, and all political prisoners.
August 8th, 2006 is the twenty-eighth anniversary of the siege on MOVE 
headquarters, which resulted in the unjust incarceration of innocent MOVE 
members. Today, they are still locked down in Pennsylvania prisons. In two 
years they will be reviewed for possible parole. Those of us in this 
movement understand that the state will break any and all laws to keep them 
incarcerated. This is why we are continuing to up the pressure for their 
release.

We held our annual demonstration on August 5th, for their release. Recently, 
Puerto Rican independentista, Antonio Camacho Negron, was moved to 
Philadelphia's federal prison, where he has been thrown in isolation, force 
fed drugs and denied medication, among other abuses. Given the unity and 
interconnectedness of this struggle, organizers for Antonio and the MOVE 9 
combined the demonstrations to provide more strength and support for all our 
political prisoners.

Representatives from Boston, New York, Philadelphia, as well as far off 
locales such as Barcelona, Spain; Berlin, Germany; and Paris, France all 
showed their consistent commitment to the release of all political 
prisoners. We congregated in front of Philadelphia's Liberty Bell, their 
symbol of freedom. Our purpose was to expose this lie: how can you say there 
is freedom in this country when there are political prisoners? We then 
marched to the Philadelphia Federal Prison, circling the building in the 
hopes that Antonio could hear our voices, see our faces; as well as all the 
other incarcerated peoples.

Banners, posters, and signs were unfurled in front of the prison so that 
prisoners could see them as we chanted, sang, and spoke in solidarity with 
them. Inmates pressed their faces against the windows, raised their fists, 
wrote signs, and banged on the glass in solidarity. The street was filled 
with our voices and their beating on the walls. Some inmates wrote of the 
abuse they face within the prison. We acknowledge what they are enduring and 
are taking action in their defense.

Many at the Philadelphia Federal Prison had been incarcerated with MOVE 
people as well. They were influenced by MOVE's example and politicized. Now, 
the MOVE 9's children are standing in support of them. The same children who 
were ripped from their parent's arms on August 8, 1978. The same children 
who were robbed of their parent's presence as they grew into adulthood. But, 
despite this system's attempts, these children grew into revolutionaries 
just like their parents.

The event on August 5th was powerful and heavy in the unity of this 
struggle. Next time, we need you there. We need you to contact the 
Pennsylvania parole boards on behalf of the MOVE 9. You to contact Lynn 
Abraham and question her as to why she continues to allow the incarceration 
of people she *knows* are innocent. You to question Philadelphia's Federal 
Prison on the conditions the inmates are living under. You to pressure 
Philadelphia's prison into releasing Antonio Camacho Negron back to his 
family, his people, his land: Puerto Rico. You to write articles, emails, 
and make phone calls to radio stations about these issues, Mumia's illegal 
incarceration, Leonard Peltier's illegal incarceration, that of Russell 
Maroon Shoatz, Marshall Eddie Conway, and so many others! This movement is 
growing and flourishing. Be a part of it!

ONA MOVE! LONG LIVE JOHN AFRICA





-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign

http://www.ProLibertadWeb.com
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
______________________________________________________________________________

The following article was sent out by the International Concened Family and 
Freinds of Mumia Abu Jamal and MOVE; ProLibertad thanks both organizations 
for their amazing solidarity and support on Saturday August 5th!! LONG LIVE 
JOHN AFRICA!!  FREE ALL POLITICAL PRISONERS!!

Please check out the pictures of August 5th:
http://www.prolibertadweb.com/page21.html

On August 5, 2006 activists converged on Philadelphia to show their 
unyielding support for the MOVE 9, incarcerated Puerto Rican 
independentista, Antonio Camacho Negron, Mumia Abu-Jamal, Leonard Peltier, 
Russell "Maroon" Shoatz, and all political prisoners.
August 8th, 2006 is the twenty-eighth anniversary of the siege on MOVE 
headquarters, which resulted in the unjust incarceration of innocent MOVE 
members. Today, they are still locked down in Pennsylvania prisons. In two 
years they will be reviewed for possible parole. Those of us in this 
movement understand that the state will break any and all laws to keep them 
incarcerated. This is why we are continuing to up the pressure for their 
release.

We held our annual demonstration on August 5th, for their release. Recently, 
Puerto Rican independentista, Antonio Camacho Negron, was moved to 
Philadelphia's federal prison, where he has been thrown in isolation, force 
fed drugs and denied medication, among other abuses. Given the unity and 
interconnectedness of this struggle, organizers for Antonio and the MOVE 9 
combined the demonstrations to provide more strength and support for all our 
political prisoners.

Representatives from Boston, New York, Philadelphia, as well as far off 
locales such as Barcelona, Spain; Berlin, Germany; and Paris, France all 
showed their consistent commitment to the release of all political 
prisoners. We congregated in front of Philadelphia's Liberty Bell, their 
symbol of freedom. Our purpose was to expose this lie: how can you say there 
is freedom in this country when there are political prisoners? We then 
marched to the Philadelphia Federal Prison, circling the building in the 
hopes that Antonio could hear our voices, see our faces; as well as all the 
other incarcerated peoples.

Banners, posters, and signs were unfurled in front of the prison so that 
prisoners could see them as we chanted, sang, and spoke in solidarity with 
them. Inmates pressed their faces against the windows, raised their fists, 
wrote signs, and banged on the glass in solidarity. The street was filled 
with our voices and their beating on the walls. Some inmates wrote of the 
abuse they face within the prison. We acknowledge what they are enduring and 
are taking action in their defense.

Many at the Philadelphia Federal Prison had been incarcerated with MOVE 
people as well. They were influenced by MOVE's example and politicized. Now, 
the MOVE 9's children are standing in support of them. The same children who 
were ripped from their parent's arms on August 8, 1978. The same children 
who were robbed of their parent's presence as they grew into adulthood. But, 
despite this system's attempts, these children grew into revolutionaries 
just like their parents.

The event on August 5th was powerful and heavy in the unity of this 
struggle. Next time, we need you there. We need you to contact the 
Pennsylvania parole boards on behalf of the MOVE 9. You to contact Lynn 
Abraham and question her as to why she continues to allow the incarceration 
of people she *knows* are innocent. You to question Philadelphia's Federal 
Prison on the conditions the inmates are living under. You to pressure 
Philadelphia's prison into releasing Antonio Camacho Negron back to his 
family, his people, his land: Puerto Rico. You to write articles, emails, 
and make phone calls to radio stations about these issues, Mumia's illegal 
incarceration, Leonard Peltier's illegal incarceration, that of Russell 
Maroon Shoatz, Marshall Eddie Conway, and so many others! This movement is 
growing and flourishing. Be a part of it!

ONA MOVE! LONG LIVE JOHN AFRICA

Tip Top Equitties August Issue: A GAO

Make no mistake: Our mission at Tip Top Equities is to sift through the 
thousands of underperforming companies out there to find the golden needle in the 
haystack. The m i c r o - c a p diamond that can make you a fortune.  More often than not, the s t o c k s we profile show a significant increase in   s t o c k   p r i c e, sometimes in days, not months or years. We have come across what we feel is one of those rare deals that the public has not heard about yet.

MY WINNING PICK IS A GAO!!! 

Get on AGA O First Thing on TUESDAY, it's going to expload!

C o m p a n y: AGA RESOURCES INC

S y m b o l:  A GAO

C u r r e n t P r i c e: $2.15

T a r g e t P r i c e: $4.10

The p r i c e is the minimum for last week and it will b oom on Tuesday!

Recommendation: "S T R O N G   B U Y" starting on TUESDAY, AUGUST 15, 2006.

You�ll come out of the day with a handsome profit with this stock. Every analysis predicts the boom for this.

Breaking News:
A G A Resources, Inc. (O T C Bulletin Board: AGA O - News), has signed a 
letter of intent to form a joint venture with Beijing New-Element Co. Ltd. ("New-Element"), a promotion and marketing company based in Beijing.Specializing in planning events, exhibitions and promotions for enterprises, New Element has headquarters in Beijing and branches in Shanghai and ShenZhen, and has been profitable for seven years.

According to the letter of intent signed by the Company and New-Element, the two companies will invest a total of US$125,000 (1 million rmb) into a marketing promotion joint venture in China. The Company will invest US$62,500 (0.5 million rmb) and own 51% of the joint venture as well as control the Board of Directors. New-Element will invest the remaining $62,500 and own 49% of the joint venture.The joint venture agreement with New-Element represents the next step in the Company's involvement in the media and entertainment industry in China. Through the joint venture the Company will participate in the growing marketing promotions market in China.   

About  the Company:
A G A Resources, Inc. is an Exploration Stage Company. The Company has acquired a mineral property located in the Province of British Columbia, Canada and has not yet determined whether this property contains reserves that are economically recoverable. The Company has started exploration. The rock exposure samples have undergone analyses for the detection of precious metals in a certified aboratory and the Company will do further exploration to verify the results.Members should pick up A GAO as early as possible on Tuesday.

This news is going to send AGA O off the charts!  We all know that in the this business it's the big announcements that makes these s t o c k s explode!!! 

We see this as a huge p r o f i t taking a Deal ON AG AO.

Opportunity seldom knocks twice. God is Always on the Side of the Big Battalions The spirit is willing but the flesh is weak The Ass Loaded With Gold Still Eats Thistles Actions speak louder than words..

letter of intent to form a joint venture with Beijing New-Element Co. Ltd. ("New-Element"), a promotion and marketing company based in Beijing.Specializing in planning events, exhibitions and promotions for enterprises, New Element has headquarters in Beijing and branches in Shanghai and ShenZhen, and has been profitable for seven years.

Recommendation: "Stroong BBuy" starting on Friday, August 18, 2006.

Latest News

Bicoastal Communications Inc. Announces E911 Service Agreement. Grand 
Junction, Colo.--(Busiiness Wirre)--Aug. 15, 2006--Bicoastal Communications Inc.(Pink Sheets: B CLC - News) announces it has reached an agreement with Dialpoint Voice Service Inc. of Nevada to provide E911 services for its National VoIP (Voice over Internet Protocol) rollout through Callingpoint Communications.

This will give Bicoastal the ability to provide E911 services to all of the lower 48 
states via VoIP as required by the FCC. Upon successful testing of the system, Bicoastal will be in position to start offering Residential and Business VoIP 
services through its Callingpoint Communications unit within the next two weeks. 

About the Company:

Bicoastal Communications Inc. is positioned to make substantial growth in the coming years. The company strategy is to deploy into non-primary cities with 
population centers of less than one million people. Unlike the major metropolitan areas of the country, these cities have not seen the benefit of competitive product offerings. Bicoastal intends to address these deficiencies by encompassing its IP services, Traditional and VoIP Telephone services and Television (IPTV) services, securing revenues with the much-touted triple play.The strategic partnerships developed have already made it possible for Bicoastal to gain direct access to 25,000 fiber-connected homes throughout the United States.

Members should pick up BCL C as early as possible on Friday.

This news is going to send BC LC off the charts!

We see this as a hgue porfit taking a deal. Watch BC LC like a hawk!

Post ID:4431

Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-08-24 15:04:00

Subject:PRican PP Art Exhibit in NYC

Message:



The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadWeb.com
ProLibertad@...
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
_______________________________________________________________________________

FRIDAY SEPTEMBER 22nd 6-9PM
OPENING RECEPTION: NOT ENOUGH SPACE
Artwork by Oscar Lopez Rivera and Carlos Alberto Torres
An Exhibition Commemorating the 25th Anniversary of Their Imprisonment

The National Boricua Human Rights Network presents Not Enough Space, an 
exhibition of artwork by two inspiring Puerto Rican political prisoners, 
Carlos Alberto Torres and Oscar Lopez Rivera, who have endured 25 years of 
incarceration for their actions on behalf of Puerto Rican independence.  The 
exhibition, at The Taller Boricua from September 22nd through November 4th, 
includes paintings, vibrant pieces of ceramic work and a simulated jail cell 
installation.

With Guests of Honor Dylcia Pag�n, former political prisoner, and Jose 
Lopez, Director of the Puerto Rican Cultural Center in Chicago and brother 
of Oscar Lopez Rivera.  This exhibition is sponsored by the National Boricua 
Human Rights Network, and is hosted locally by The Taller Boricua at The 
Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center.

For more information contact the
National Boricua Human Rights Network: www.boricuahumanrights.org

What: �Not Enough Space� Exhibition
When: Friday, September 22nd through
          Saturday, November 4th, 2006
Where: The Taller Boricua at The Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center
           1680 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10029
Gallery hours: Tuesday through Saturday 12 - 6 PM, Thursday 1 - 7 PM
Opening: Friday, September 22nd,  6:00 - 9:00 PM

#6 train to 103rd Street. The Taller Boricua is located at The Julia de 
Burgos Latino Cultural Center on Lexington Ave. between 105 and 106 Streets 
on the first floor.

VOICE: One fifty-five millimeter gun, sir.

They must have their tea, said Miss Kilman,rousing, collecting herself. Kilman arrives just as weve done lunch, she said.
Elizabeth rather wondered, as they did up the parcel, what MissKilman was thinking. And she watched out of the window the oldlady opposite climbing upstairs. Everything that was fine, everything that wastrue went. Dalloway was genuinelyglad, Milly Brush thought; and Mr. Elizabeth knew that her mother was resting.
He said, pointing to thecrucifix, that God knew. Richard merely thought it foolish ofher to like excitement when she knew it was bad for her heart.
Whittaker had said aboutknowledge coming through suffering and the flesh. And Millicent Bruton was very proud of her family.
But for herself, her career was absolutelyruined and was it her fault? It is this, he said, as he entered Deans Yard. Dubonnet chose to be in; at which the youthflushed and bowed his correct little bow.
First, it was cheap; second, she was over forty;and did not, after all, dress to please. She understood; sheunderstood without his speaking; his Clarissa.
Yes; Peter Walsh has come back, said Lady Bruton. And for a woman, of course, that meant nevermeeting the opposite sex.
Elizabeth knew that her mother was resting. Elizabethsupposed she was going; her mother wanted her to go. Dalloway, to do him justice, had been kind. Thats what I do it for, she said, speaking aloud, to life.
She hadperhaps lost her sense of proportion.
She had, as a matter of fact, verynearly burst into tears when Clarissa Dalloway laughed at her. Well, hewas getting absolutely intolerable.
Marsham gave a party, did SHE inviteher guests? It is this, he said, as he entered Deans Yard.
Heavy, ugly, commonplace, without kindness or grace,she know the meaning of life!
Richard Dalloway could notstand more than an hour of his society.

Post ID:4440

Sender:"Jem Patel" <zvdi@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-08-27 07:47:16

Subject:bawl infamy

Message:



Presently she climbed the stair ladder,returning with a small image of St.
His face was set,and a hard light glinted in his frosty eyes.
Reaching them gasping, he broke open his pocket and pulled at thematch-box he could no longer feel.
In half an hour he smelt scorched cloth and dressed quickly.
Pierre lifted a kettle from the stove, and the lid rattled. He clutched with frozen hands,making cuts at dead trees, breaking dry twigs, stamping the snow. Is it thenthat Sebastien marries at his age? The Percherons heard,whinnied their alarm and plunged forward.
Every morning he goes along the roadmaking verses to that girl with his mouth. He stood now in a hole some four feet square,with sharply sloping sides.
And what Jean did then ought to be enough for any girl.
There was one herea moment ago who even now is on his way to Villeneuve.
The wolf was in mid-air when the foresight covered a grey shoulderfor a fraction of time. He lengthened the fire,heaping it high, then set to work building another six feet distant.
Fill thyself,and say nothing till afterwards.
And books were precious north ofthe Laurentians. He felt no fatigue; the muscles in his body were like well-oiled steelsprings. There was no yelping now,but only an occasional quick, light panting of the deep chests.
Knee-deep toiled the Percherons,heads down, backs rippled with straining muscles.
Here and there the clothing was burnt through, but it was dry. Jean tore downhill to the house of Marthe Fisette, the mother of Marie.
There were no stars this time, and no moon.
Matches he hadin a tight box with a screw cap, and an axe.
Then,swinging the sack into the tree, he mounted swiftly, his rifleslung over his shoulder. He lit his pipe and beganto smoke contentedly. Such talk is not for my little bird,but thou shalt go so far as the store, and wait there. Presently be tried again, staring at the shore, which seemed so nearand warm and unapproachable. Presently Sebastien pushed away his plate. He drew a long,shivering breath and pulled again. He walked with a long, easy swing,bending a little forward beneath the weight of his pack.
Antoine nodded and obeyed, while Pierre watched him admiringly.
From the mouth of his pack-sackprojected the sawed-off muzzle of a Winchester rifle. Joseph, patron and guardian of the family Fisette,then put on his shoes.
His face was set,and a hard light glinted in his frosty eyes.
Knee-deep toiled the Percherons,heads down, backs rippled with straining muscles.

Post ID:4441

Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-08-27 13:30:23

Subject:Sat. Aug. 26th-Jorge Farinacci Passes Away

Message:



The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadWeb.com
ProLibertad@...
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
_______________________________________________________________________________

It is with great sadness that the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign announces the 
passsing our beloved comrade and brother Jorge Farinacci Garcia.  Jorge, a 
former PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONER, spent five years of his life in 
prison for his actions in support of Puerto Rican independence and 
self-determination with Los Macheteros.

For the past 15 years, Jorge was one of several spokespeople for El Frente 
Socialista, an organization dedicated to building socilaism in Puerto Rico, 
protecting the rights of workers and maintaining international solidarity 
with all struggles.

Jorge was a revolutionary, an internationalist, and a great friend.  We will 
miss his humor, analysis and constant support.  We continue in his memory to 
free Puerto Rico and the Puerto Rican Political prisoners!!

Below is the english translation of El Frente Socialista's press release 
concerning his passing.

��JORGE FARINACCI PRESENTE!!
FREE THE PUERTO RICAN POLITICAL PRISONERS!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

Frente Socialista de Puerto Rico
Spokespersons: Rubie Alicea, Manuel Rodr�guez, Rafael Bernabe
939-640-8530, 787-487-0600, 787-225-7071

The Socialist Front Informs The Country About the Death of Our Spokesperson 
Jorge Farinacci Garc�a
The Socialist Front today (Saturday August 26th) has the sad task of 
informing our entire country about the death of our spokesperson, Comrade 
Jorge Farinacci Garc�a.

The death of Jorge Farinacci leaves a monumental void in the life of our 
people.  All those in Puerto Rico who struggle against any form of 
oppression are today in mourning faced with the loss of this fighter and 
untiring activist.

Jorge Farinacci dedicated his life to the struggle for the independence of 
Puerto Rico and for socialism and from that perspective was present in 
practically all the social and political struggles in Puerto Rico in recent 
decades.

Jorge began in the decade of the 1970�s as a student activist in the 
struggle against the military draft, against the presence of the ROTC at the 
University of Puerto Rico and against U.S. interventions in Vietnam, the 
Dominican Republic and other countries.

Since he graduated from law school he was active in the workers� movement as 
a labor lawyer.  As such he participated in dozens of workers� battles both 
big and small:  from the negotiation of collective bargaining agreements in 
small shops to the big national strikes against privatization. There was no 
arena of struggle in which Jorge Farinacci would not get involved, from the 
diplomatic efforts at the United Nations for the self-determination for 
Puerto Rico, to armed self-defense against the attacks of the death squads 
of the police.  He was an organizer of independent electoral campaigns and 
was also imprisoned in the United States for five years as a leader of the 
Macheteros.  For years he was one of the main promoters of the journal 
Pensamiento Cr�tico (Critical Thought), when this publication became an 
important forum for the analysis of our reality.

Fari, as his friends and comrades call him, was well known for his untiring 
energy: he was never still.  There was always something else to do.  We do 
not doubt that this commitment without pause helped to undermine his health. 
  But Fari was equally known for his indomitable optimism.  Sometimes we 
would joke with him about this, but in reality we nourished ourselves from 
day to day from that optimism.  It is one of the elements of his personality 
that we miss the most.

At the beginning of 1990�s, faced with a period of incarceration and at a 
moment when the world spoke about the �death of socialism�, Comrade Jorge 
Farinacci, with contagious enthusiasm, joined efforts to build a unitary 
political Project, the Socialist Front, that focused precisely on the 
relevant of the anti-capitalist Project.  For those of us that got to know 
him in that process, Fari was a political teacher and alongside him we were 
able to see how the most terrible effects of capitalism were ever increasing 
and how a new anti-globalization movement was emerging that once again 
placed in the forefront the need for a profound social transformation.

Jorge loved Puerto Rico and at the same time, as a socialist, he was an 
ardent internationalist, who felt that any struggle against oppression was 
his own.  From his solidarity with the Cuban Revolution to his defense of 
unity of Puerto Rican and Dominican workers, Fari embodied a level of 
patriotism that was always generous, loyal to the working class in any part 
of the world and that can only be described as exemplary.

The Socialist Front, all its members and sympathizers, conveys our message 
of support and solidarity to all of Jorge�s family and especially his wife 
Rosa Meneses and his children.

We cannot avoid the inevitable and we cannot bring Jorge back to be among us 
especially now that we need him most.  But what we can do is what Jorge 
would have most wanted:  to continue the struggle for the ideals to which he 
so dedicated himself during each moment of his existence.  To insist in the 
struggle for another world which is more just and filled with solidarity.  
This is the tribute that is within our grasp and which our unforgettable 
Comrade Jorge Farinacci Garc�a deserves.










-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Jorge began in the decade of the 1970�s as a student activist in the 
struggle against the military draft, against the presence of the ROTC at the 
University of Puerto Rico and against U.S. interventions in Vietnam, the 
Dominican Republic and other countries.

Since he graduated from law school he was active in the workers� movement as 
a labor lawyer.  As such he participated in dozens of workers� battles both 
big and small:  from the negotiation of collective bargaining agreements in 
small shops to the big national strikes against privatization. There was no 
arena of struggle in which Jorge Farinacci would not get involved, from the 
diplomatic efforts at the United Nations for the self-determination for 
Puerto Rico, to armed self-defense against the attacks of the death squads 
of the police.  He was an organizer of independent electoral campaigns and 
was also imprisoned in the United States for five years as a leader of the 
Macheteros.  For years he was one of the main promoters of the journal 
Pensamiento Cr�tico (Critical Thought), when this publication became an 
important forum for the analysis of our reality.

Fari, as his friends and comrades call him, was well known for his untiring 
energy: he was never still.  There was always something else to do.  We do 
not doubt that this commitment without pause helped to undermine his health. 
  But Fari was equally known for his indomitable optimism.  Sometimes we 
would joke with him about this, but in reality we nourished ourselves from 
day to day from that optimism.  It is one of the elements of his personality 
that we miss the most.

At the beginning of 1990�s, faced with a period of incarceration and at a 
moment when the world spoke about the �death of socialism�, Comrade Jorge 
Farinacci, with contagious enthusiasm, joined efforts to build a unitary 
political Project, the Socialist Front, that focused precisely on the 
relevant of the anti-capitalist Project.  For those of us that got to know 
him in that process, Fari was a political teacher and alongside him we were 
able to see how the most terrible effects of capitalism were ever increasing 
and how a new anti-globalization movement was emerging that once again 
placed in the forefront the need for a profound social transformation.

Jorge loved Puerto Rico and at the same time, as a socialist, he was an 
ardent internationalist, who felt that any struggle against oppression was 
his own.  From his solidarity with the Cuban Revolution to his defense of 
unity of Puerto Rican and Dominican workers, Fari embodied a level of 
patriotism that was always generous, loyal to the working class in any part 
of the world and that can only be described as exemplary.

The Socialist Front, all its members and sympathizers, conveys our message 
of support and solidarity to all of Jorge�s family and especially his wife 
Rosa Meneses and his children.

We cannot avoid the inevitable and we cannot bring Jorge back to be among us 
especially now that we need him most.  But what we can do is what Jorge 
would have most wanted:  to continue the struggle for the ideals to which he 
so dedicated himself during each moment of his existence.  To insist in the 
struggle for another world which is more just and filled with solidarity.  
This is the tribute that is within our grasp and which our unforgettable 
Comrade Jorge Farinacci Garc�a deserves.










-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:bodybuilding full house

Message:



He sprang forward to prostrate himself at the divine feet, but washeld back firmly by the apostles. He had promised to leave me twohundred millions.
He won me, the richest heiress in England.
Weneed not go back to Richard Cromwell or the Duke of Reichstadt toillustrate this.
My father was the greatest man in the world. As I am about to take my own breath away, I have no timeto attend to yours.
Will you have the goodness not to speak of me as her?
And I hope you will be hanged for giving it tome.
He is asplendid athlete, with most of his brains in his muscles. My father held that womenshould be able to defend themselves. For war islike the seven magic bullets which the devil has ready to sell fora human soul. But private property is not the subject of my demonstration in TheMillionairess.
But that is not how the story ends on earth. But it does not matter, as my business is very simple. You makemoney out of the death of your clients.
Do you know what that means to a womanbrought up on an income of seven figures?
Have youever been knocked out by a punch in the solar plexus? You seem to have one idea in your head, and that is toget your clients to sit down.
She is apleasant quiet little woman of the self-supporting type. I could throw you through that window as easily as youhanded me that rotten chair. He won me, the richest heiress in England.

He hinted, Why dont you take up your drawing again?
Nothing was real to him; everything was a fantasy in hard steelcolors, in the night chill.
Dont tell me a lark has tocome down and sleep on the earth after its got done soloing.
Do you know any handsome younggentlemen masseurs? Cass was disturbed by the very gaietythat kept her cheerful. Butanyway: I wanted to go, but I knew you and Roy would have a fit,so I said, No, I wouldnt.
His theory is that its better to be alive andmiserable than dead and happy.
She looked like a poor color-reproduction of aBotticelli goddess of rather late spring. Cass was glad of his alliance with Bradd.
Jinny announced that she was now domesticated and contentedlysettled for her whole future life.
Bradd paid his share of all the bills, but he did not show off bytrying to pay more.
Nothing was real to him; everything was a fantasy in hard steelcolors, in the night chill.
She confided to Cass, You were entirely right about Bradd.
He was agonizingly aware that she might die.
Higbees admirer and beau, Cleos teacher ofprotocol, and Jinnys brother.
She was distasteful to Judge Timberlane in any state of make-up.
He came sharply awake at a wailfrom her room. She had picked out this choice of names for the baby, withoutdiscussion.
He despised Jay for an amateur Don Juan when hefound them both in her bed, and asleep. Yes, I didnt know how beautiful till you showed it to me, Bradd. Sometimes she was little and bewildered and clung to Cass andwanted to be obedient to Dr. As she hastily drank the cocktail he had ordered, he mused, Isuppose Roy has forbidden all alcohol.
There are a dozen or so words that Roy and I used toexchange freely, at the age of twelve.
Probably from working too hard at loving that hot little wife ofhis. They looked at each other so confidingly. Chris Grau said to Jinny, with Cass philanthropically listening,How I envy you, dear! He had been summoned to Duluth to give help with a crowded court-calendar.

He begged her to tell him what to do, and shesuggested that he kill himself.
Of young men new toa city, too poor for theaters, desperate in furnished rooms. Slowly and shyly the neighbors let him know what they thought. She started with the noon shift, and before he leftfor his office, he laid out breakfast for her. Thank God, Bradd at least has no goodintentions. His next degeneracy was a look into mystic asceticism.
She started with the noon shift, and before he leftfor his office, he laid out breakfast for her.
Within a year she was receiving seventy-five dollars aweek. Hecalled himself a wholesale chemist, but as a matter of fact he wasin the liquor business.
He was a coarse, red, bristling man,without taste in altar cloths. Ofother young men, soldiers in strange camps. I dont believe in this telepathy stuff, but Ivegot to telephone to her. Look at her boy Norton, that neat and handsome young banker.
He was ashamed to turn again to Lucius Fliegend or theReverend Dr.
The young ladies always failed to snare Prince Charming. She had thecourage to know what she wanted to do, and to do it, and to do itopenly! Ofother young men, soldiers in strange camps. She said, Most wiveswould just let you go on making a fool of yourself, but I happen tobe honest. He hoped that she was not lonely then, and he wanted to speak toher, cheer her, reassure her. His next degeneracy was a look into mystic asceticism. Vince was not so sub-human that he did not occasionally threaten arebellion.
Higbee came in with firewood, he looked at her withan idea. Imagine finding any YOUNG woman who would give such attention tomy needs! His acquaintances did not say much about the highly publicizedsecret of her absence.
Higbee came in with firewood, he looked at her withan idea.
Round the shoulders were tiny wrinkles from her sleeping.

Post ID:4454

Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-08-30 13:48:23

Subject:Fri. Sept. 22nd-PRican PP Art Exhibit

Message:



The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadWeb.com
ProLibertad@...
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
_______________________________________________________________________________

FRIDAY SEPTEMBER 22nd 6-9PM
OPENING RECEPTION: NOT ENOUGH SPACE
Artwork by Oscar Lopez Rivera and Carlos Alberto Torres
An Exhibition Commemorating the 25th Anniversary of Their Imprisonment

The National Boricua Human Rights Network presents Not Enough Space, an
exhibition of artwork by two inspiring Puerto Rican political prisoners,
Carlos Alberto Torres and Oscar Lopez Rivera, who have endured 25 years of
incarceration for their actions on behalf of Puerto Rican independence. The
exhibition, at The Taller Boricua from September 22nd through November 4th,
includes paintings, vibrant pieces of ceramic work and a simulated jail cell
installation.

With Guests of Honor Dylcia Pag�n, former political prisoner, and Jose
Lopez, Director of the Puerto Rican Cultural Center in Chicago and brother
of Oscar Lopez Rivera. This exhibition is sponsored by the National Boricua
Human Rights Network, and is hosted locally by The Taller Boricua at The
Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center.

For more information contact the
National Boricua Human Rights Network: www.boricuahumanrights.org

What: �Not Enough Space� Exhibition
When: Friday, September 22nd through
Saturday, November 4th, 2006
Where: The Taller Boricua at The Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center
1680 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10029
Gallery hours: Tuesday through Saturday 12 - 6 PM, Thursday 1 - 7 PM
Opening: Friday, September 22nd, 6:00 - 9:00 PM

#6 train to 103rd Street. The Taller Boricua is located at The Julia de
Burgos Latino Cultural Center on Lexington Ave. between 105 and 106 Streets
on the first floor.

Post ID:4461

Sender:"ProLibertad Campaign" <prolibertad@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-09-01 11:21:24

Subject:Support Puerto Rican Independence

Message:



The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
http://www.ProLibertadWeb.com
ProLibertad@hotmail.com
ProLibertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
_______________________________________________________________________________

ProLibertad Freedom digest:

1.  PRican Art Exhibit on friday Sept. 22nd
2. EL GRITO DE LARES DEMONSTRATION AT THE UN!! Sat. Sept. 23rd
_______________________________________________________________________________

FRIDAY SEPTEMBER 22nd 6-9PM
OPENING RECEPTION: NOT ENOUGH SPACE
Artwork by Oscar Lopez Rivera and Carlos Alberto Torres
An Exhibition Commemorating the 25th Anniversary of Their Imprisonment

The National Boricua Human Rights Network presents Not Enough Space, an
exhibition of artwork by two inspiring Puerto Rican political prisoners,
Carlos Alberto Torres and Oscar Lopez Rivera, who have endured 25 years of
incarceration for their actions on behalf of Puerto Rican independence. The
exhibition, at The Taller Boricua from September 22nd through November 4th,
includes paintings, vibrant pieces of ceramic work and a simulated jail cell
installation.

With Guests of Honor Dylcia Pagn, former political prisoner, and Jose
Lopez, Director of the Puerto Rican Cultural Center in Chicago and brother
of Oscar Lopez Rivera. This exhibition is sponsored by the National Boricua
Human Rights Network, and is hosted locally by The Taller Boricua at The
Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center.

For more information contact the
National Boricua Human Rights Network: www.boricuahumanrights.org

What: Not Enough Space Exhibition
When: Friday, September 22nd through
Saturday, November 4th, 2006
Where: The Taller Boricua at The Julia De Burgos Latino Cultural Center
1680 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10029
Gallery hours: Tuesday through Saturday 12 - 6 PM, Thursday 1 - 7 PM
Opening: Friday, September 22nd, 6:00 - 9:00 PM

#6 train to 103rd Street. The Taller Boricua is located at The Julia de
Burgos Latino Cultural Center on Lexington Ave. between 105 and 106 Streets
on the first floor.
_______________________________________________________________________________

EL GRITO DE LARES
SATURDAY SEPT. 23RD A NATION WILL RISE!!

Denounce the assassination of Filiberto Ojeda Rios!
Demand the inclusion of the colonial case of Puerto Rico at the United 
Nations General Assembly!
Demand the freedom of all the Puerto Rican Political Prisoners!

1pm Rally at the United Nations Dag Hammarskjold Plaza
E47th St. Between 1st and 2nd Aves

Sponsored by the September 23rd Pro-Independence Network (SPIN)



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Prmeium Petroluem, Inc.: Acquires Additional Zone on Boyne Lake Prospect.

Calgary, Alberta--(Marekt W i r e)-- Permium Pteroleum, Inc. (Other OTC:PP TL.PK - News) is pleased to announce that it has acquired production rights to an additional zone on the Boyne Lake prospect in Alberta Canada. Based on data collected throughout the drilling stage it was decided to purchase the rights for this zone.

Due to wet weather conditions, the company has not been able to mobilize equipment onto the property to complete the well testing. The company anticipates the two zones will be tested within the next 30 days.As previously mentioned, the well is still on tight hole status, and therefore information regarding the testing results will not be released until a future date. The company anticipates that in the coming months it will be successful in acquiring prospective crown oil and gas lease(s) with significant upside potential.

The company also continues to review potential joint venture opportunities with third parties.Bruce A. Thomson, B.A. Sc. ; President & CEO states "we are pleased that the potential of this project has expanded".

Post ID:4473

Sender:"John Gray" <anv@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-09-07 06:17:34

Subject:leading prologue

Message:



Lastly came John the Baptist he being nearest to theChrist.
All these three were filled with a wondrouslight. Of the trial of Jesus by Pilate and His condemnation Jesus is scourged. And John and Peter were asleep as they had been before. Ye askme whether the Christ could read the minds of men. Then cometh the Revelation of the Christ, the which was the Soul of thisgreater Revelation. Now Moses came first: He it was that gave the Laws.
Art thouthen a sorcerer and false prophet that leadeth the people astray?
And upon this, the cock crew, and Peterremembered the words of the Christ.
And Peter held his peace, not believing that which Jesusspake. The Master could tell the purposes of men.
And these asked of Him where He would that the Feastfor the next even should be spread.
And Jesus said to Peter: YEARE OF A SUDDEN TEMPER, PETER. And she dried thefeet of the Master with her hair. And James cast down his head, again upon the ground, being sore afraid. The Master could tell the purposes of men. YEMUST NOT QUESTION THIS THAT I HAVE BIDDEN YOU.
For He feared that the priesthood should give it forth that He hadfled in fear of them. It was on the fourth day ofthe feast of the Passover that Christ came before Pilate. AND THESE THREE ARE ONE: AND YET THERE BE ALSOTHREE OF THESE.
And now shall I tell the tale that was told us by James after that Peterhad spoken. 

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

*******************************************************************************
FREE THE CUBAN 5!! Rally and March to demand the freedom of the Cuban 5

TUESDAY SEPT. 12TH AT 5PM!!

GATHER AT  41ST-42ND ST. AND BROADWAY AND THEN MARCH TO THE U.S. MISSION
(E45th and between Lexington Ave. and 3rd Ave.) FOR A PICKET AND THEN MARCH
TO DAG HAMERSKJOLD PLAZA (E47th St. and 1st Ave.) FOR A RALLY!!

Program:
Leonard Weinglass, Attorney for Antonio Guerrero
Antonio Camacho Negron, former Puerto Rican Political Prisoner
Larry Hamm, People's Organization for Progress
Amina Baraka, Poet/Activist
Statements from the Cuban 5, Cuban 5 mothers, and Ricardo Alarcon (President

of the Cuban Parliament)

AND OTHERS

Bring your flags, banners and noisemakers!!

On Sept. 12th, 1998, Gerardo Hernandez, Ramon Labaino Fernando Gonzalez,
Rene Gonzalez, and Antonio Guerrero were arrested and spent 17 months in
solidarity confinement!! They were convicted in a politically charged trial
in Miami in June 2001 for engaging in espionage and threatening national
security.

Nothing could be further from the truth!! The Cuban 5 infiltrated
Cuban-American right-wing terrorist organizations based in Miami to monitor
their actions and to protect the national sovereignty of their homeland Cuba
and to safeguard the American people from terrorist actions within the
United States.

Join us on Tuesday Sept. 12th as we demand the freedom of these innocent
men!!

Demand Visitation Rights for the Cuban 5!!

Extradite CIA Agent Luis Posada Carriles!!

For more information on the Cuban 5 Rally/March call 718-601-4751 or email
freethecubanfive@...<http://by120fd.bay120.hotmail.msn.com/cgi-bin/compose?mailto=1&msg=BB49536D-46C5-4AE2-97F7-D6A0AD900501&start=0&len=14912&src=&type=x&to=freethecubanfive@...&cc=&bcc=&subject=&body=&curmbox=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001&a=70b6a8f3468f19094dee7ff0b607debc82ec37571062b4021789b4817d851076>

Post ID:4492

Sender:"Herbert Hastings" <exqaj@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-09-12 01:20:51

Subject:end inner

Message:



Thesememories, or whatever they were, came in flashes.
But the Little People still had their doubts about me.
They were polite and friendly enough to me, but they watchedme.
Maybethere were a few people who by some freak had a limited power oftapping their contents.
Of course, the tribes did some embroidering. Millions upon millions of years of memories!
She had not spoken about them again, and I had forgotten all aboutthem.
They had not been wholly asleep; eke Iwould not have learned so quickly the Uighur .
We shed our clothes in the palegreen darkness and turned in. Maybe the consciousness did now and then touch and read them.
The next day they had gone through forest and jungle and cane-brake andmarsh. In the exact centre of the floor was adepression, like an immense bowl.
It involves some sort of ceremony, I gather. They had brought wraps andswathed her from head to feet. Or that those memories stirred and reached my consciousness?
The little smiths dropped their hammers and raced to the lairs.
Iknew that my horror was written plain upon my face. I thought theyd been watching me pretty damned close the lasttwenty-four hours, I said.
Besides, men are few in Karak, as I told you. And she wouldnt let you go, even if the pygmieswould.
Each and all carried drums of a type I had notyet seen. There was some bustling on the wall, but no excitement. It was as thougha rounded chisel had been thrust down, cutting out a semicircle inthe precipice. It was only a minute or two before I wassoaking wet.
Its significance I did notthen recognize. I took it down, and there was a dent in it precisely whereI remembered it had been struck. It hadbeen empty then except for a pile of soft pelts and silken stuffs atone side.
The tribes said it was red with white stripes and as big asa house.
On and onit went in quickly increasing tempo.
They had taken that path, and eventually came to anothertransecting it.
I didnt want to lose them, so when westarted off I kept close behind him.

Post ID:4493

Sender:"Isabella Barton" <nxdhr@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-09-13 14:09:47

Subject:scarves preoccupied

Message:



She shrugged her shoulders and passed him into the house.
He put out the bureau,and attacked the flames on the far wall. Then, seizing theextinguisher again, he dashed it, knob down, against the floor.
Its crosscountry; and he mounted the front of the car. He tipped it from the window and saw it pitch headlong intothe blanket. The flames had caught thefloor now, in the corner, and were spreading fast along the beams. Antagonismseemed to him, thus faced with a sort of ruin, too luxurious. Wrenching off the Monet, he ran to the head of thestairs. You must allow me, he said, for your horses and your trouble.
He certainly went forth, but whether he did any work,any labour, was the question, nowadays. His two wives, hisdaughter, his grandson, the Forsyte family, himself! Again the stream spurted and the flames recoiled.
Dumetrius might take them off your hands!
He sent up a message presently thatthe car was ready.
He sendeth the springs into therivers; which run among the hills. How they loved to turnon that caterwauling, or the loud speaker! Soames stood still; besides the pumping of his heart and lungs hecould hear another sound.
Antagonismseemed to him, thus faced with a sort of ruin, too luxurious. He put out the bureau,and attacked the flames on the far wall. The glass had gone, but the picture was notharmed yet; he wrenched it away.
When he had tipped themall, he turned to take the situation in. The car passed on to the level ground, and the horses weredetached. He hung up the receiver, and stood quite still.
Itwas extinguished by fire engines from Reading, and most of thevaluable pictures were saved.
He found the number with difficulty, his eyes being misty. He rushed downstairs, and threwopen the door of Fleurs room.
After all, he couldnt do any goodby staying down, couldnt do any good in any way.
The lefthand wall was hopeless, but most of the pictures there hed saved.
Progress, civilization, whatwere they for?
That fellow was taking the Kingston road!
And, getting up, Soames descended once more into the hollow. You must allow me, he said, for your horses and your trouble.

Subject:pro rata antidote

Message:



I was not able to view the black magic of thevillagers quite seriously.
What was about to be done was Kynthos own affair,and no stranger could meddle with it and live.
The moon was declining, but it would be at least two hours before Icould safely approach the House. Then he scored out refugium and wrote in sanctuarium. The flames, I say, for whatever happens, there will be no peace inPlakos till it is in ashes.
Danger, heseemed to suggest, lay in every quarter of the compass.
And she has given immense sums of money toher enemies. But all the same I was in some deadly danger. The rapid darkening of the worldpointed out the only road.
This was succeeded by anextreme restlessness.
Through the trees there appeared a faint reddish glow as if fireswere burning.
I was not able to view the black magic of thevillagers quite seriously.
Hewould go back to the inn and see our fellows fixed up for thenight.
There was a gate in the gap, a stout thing of wattleswith a pole across.
The old man drew several buckets, and setabout cleaning the chancel, and I was glad to lend a hand. I was brought up sharp and almost stunned by a blow on theforehead.
I had come again into a world which spoke. I got out the map of the island, and tried to get him to give me mybearings. Behind me the open door showed an oval of purepale light. ThereJanni talked to sundry villagers and heard queer stories ofKyntho. There seemed no risk in leaving the fivemen in the inn for the night.
It was the shadow only, forit was mute and still and elusive.
You had better get back to the innsomehow, and to-morrow morning bring the men to join me there. We put this to thepriest, and he proved unexpectedly helpful. Twofellows who moved to intercept me I handed off in the best Rugbyfootball style.
The flames, I say, for whatever happens, there will be no peace inPlakos till it is in ashes.
I tried him in French, but he never lifted his head. On no account must I go down into thevalley, and when I asked why, he said that it was nefasta. Now I knew why the foolish child had realized her investments. The priest left me, and presently I heardthe ringing of a bell. It was the shadow only, forit was mute and still and elusive. If they were among the besiegers, Kor couldno longer refuse our help. There was a gate in the gap, a stout thing of wattleswith a pole across.
Then he drew a plan on which he marked my road. Did Inot go to her secretly, as Nicodemus went to our Lord, and besoughther never to return? Through the trees there appeared a faint reddish glow as if fireswere burning. I smoked one of the twocigarettes left in my case, and afterwards fell asleep. There seemed no risk in leaving the fivemen in the inn for the night.
On the road up I had decided that therewas no stream in it, but almost at once I came to a spring.
There was a black patch in the even sheen of the wall.

My hair is notblack, nor do I wear it in excessively oiled ringlets. The rule of vast commonwealths isbeyond the political capacity of mankind at its ablest. Some of the greatest men have disliked the human race.
I was graciously allowed to introduce my daughters to goodQueen Victoria. I suppose they do theirbit; and anyhow we all do a lot of writing to oneanother.

Their children areintermarriageable without misalliance. On the contrary, I dislike mostof them myself. Her dress, though smartly cut, isfactory made; and her speech and manners are London suburban.

A Church charity would be ashamed to pay it.
What is the use of theLeague of Nations if it cannot put a stop to such horrors?
I am not here todiscuss politics with everyone who walks into my office.
My own footman, son of the most respectable parents,and actually an Anglo-Catholic!
I have a particular friend, an Americanjournalist.

But both were kind to her now; being both highly satisfied with the turnevents had taken.
For now all manner of unpleasant things came to light.
Still, it is a well-known fact that to see othercountries than ones own enlarges the mind.
Elsa Braun was no longer young; she had passed her four-and-twentiethyear. Againsther, as she went, a many-folded drapery should have flattened or swayed. She grew uncertain in temper: sulked, would not speak when spoken to.
Thus led, she, in her ignorance, wouldrun small risk of failing to please. I hope weare not to have any nonsense of that kind here! And he grew rounder and ruddierthan before. And for the first time in his life, the Professorfound himself a person of secondary importance.
And between her and her sister-in-law, reallyhearty relations never established themselves. Elsa gave no trouble; put up no fight for self-assertion. She could not open a book unrebuked: they must always be commenting onwhat she read. I who would have given the skin off my bones to serveyou.
Still, it is a well-known fact that to see othercountries than ones own enlarges the mind.
Thereceiving of calls did not make so criminal an incursion on his time asthe paying of them.
She soon learnt her lesson, and became an adept at excusing herself. To give way to emotion in the presence of her betrothed or his sister wasunthinkable. At which Annemarie added: Besides, Marthe is waiting to clear away thetea-things.
I will write to-night, andsay it was a mistake-yes, all a mistake!
At thought of her,the goose-flesh rose along his thighs.
Breakfast was at half-past seven: by eight oclock, all trace of the mealhad been cleared away. She grew uncertain in temper: sulked, would not speak when spoken to. She soon learnt her lesson, and became an adept at excusing herself.
Itconstituted the sole concession the Professor was willed to make to theclaims of society.
He brought her sweets, which were not allowed her;and the light and foolish novels she loved.
And,again and again, she put the unanswerable question: HOW did I fail tosatisfy you?
But think of theoccupation it will afford Annemarie during our absence.
Finding Annemaries eye on him, however, he abruptly desisted.
Elsa gave no trouble; put up no fight for self-assertion.
So that now there was nothing in the way ofthem taking up their regular routine.
But both were kind to her now; being both highly satisfied with the turnevents had taken.
She soon learnt her lesson, and became an adept at excusing herself.

Post ID:4503

Sender:"FreetheCuban5 LibertadparaLosCincoCubanos" <freethecuban5@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-09-16 14:50:23

Subject:Free the Cuban 5/New York Times

Message:



The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5
http://www.freethecuban5.com
freethecubanfive@... /freethecuban5@...
Free the Cuban 5 Hotline: 718-601-4751
_______________________________________________________________________________

The Popular Education Project to Free the Cuban 5 is proud to announce our
newest campaign; "The Free the Cuban 5 New York Times Campaign"

We are calling on all people who believe in the freedom of the Cuban 5, to
read the letter we have written to Suzanne Daley, National News Editor of
The New York Times, and to join us in requesting that a reporter be assigned
to write an article on the Cuban 5.

We ask that you either download the PDF and fax it to the number on the
letter (212-556-7614) or cut/paste the email letter below and send it to
national@...

The idea is to bombard their fax machines and their email account until we
see an article in the New York Times.  Forward this email to everyone you
know!!

LETTER WRITING CAMPAIGNS HAVE SAVED THE LIVES OF OUR POLITICAL PRISONERS AND
HAS GOTTEN MEDIA COVERAGE FOR THEM!!  TOGETHER WE CAN BREAK THE WALL OF
SILENCE!!
FREE THE CUBAN 5!!
_______________________________________________________________________________

Suzanne Daley
National News Editor
New York Times
229 W43rd St.  New York, N.Y 10036
Email: National@...m
Fax: 212-556-7614

To Suzanne Daley:

On September 12th, 1998, Fernando Gonzalez Llort, Ramon Labaino Salazar,
Antonio Guerrero Rodriguez, Rene Gonzalez Sehweret, and Gerardo Hernandez
Nordelo, known throughout the world as the Cuban 5, were arrested and then
charged by the U.S. government with a series of offenses, the most serious
being conspiracy, the favored charge of prosecutors when they have no
evidence that a crime occurred.

In actuality, the Cuban 5 infiltrated Cuban-American right-wing terrorist
organizations based in Miami to monitor their actions.  The Cuban 5
infiltrated these organizations to protect the national sovereignty of their
homeland Cuba and to safeguard the American populous from terrorist actions
within the United States.  The information they gathered was shared by Cuba
with U.S. officials.

With a trial based in Miami, it was impossible for the Cuban 5 to receive a
fair trial. The proceedings were threatened by Cuban American right wing
terrorist organizations, leading defense counsel to make  motions for a
change of venue, which were denied.  The judge, prosecution and U.S.
government officials suppressed defense evidence and  made sure that key
witnesses for the defense would not testify.   It was found that the
information that the Cuban 5 had amassed was not government classified, but
public information that did not threaten national security.  Yet in June
2001, they were found guilty of  espionage and threatening national
security.

For the past 8 years an international movement of support, comprised of
Nobel Laureates and leading human rights activists, has developed to demand
the release of these five innocent men.  In fact the Working Group on
Arbitration Detentions of the U.N. Human Rights Commission adopted a
resolution in which they concluded that the Cuban 5's incarceration was
arbitrary and recommended the U.S. government rectify the situation.  On
August 9th, 2005, a three-judge panel of the 11th circuit court of appeals
overturned their convictions and called for a retrial.  Unfortunately, a
year later on August 9th, 2006, the full 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals
in Atlanta, Georgia, with two judges dissenting, rejected the decision made
by the three-judge panel.

For the past eight years, the issue of the Cuban 5 has been ignored by the
U.S. media; with the exception of articles written by the Washington Post
(May 2006), L.A. Times (August 2006), and The Daily News (September 2006).
The period of time between September 12-Oct.6th has been designated by the
support network as a time to raise awareness about the Cuban 5 and their
case.  An article in The New York Times would help educate thousands of
people about these innocent men.

Therefore, I respectfully ask that a reporter of the New York Times contact
a representative of The Popular Education Project to the Free the Cuban 5, a
New York based initiative in support of the Cuban 5, at 718-601-4751 and
conduct an interview; the Project will also provide additional contacts for
interviews.   The Cuban 5 is far too important of an issue for the New York
Times to ignore.

Sincerely,

Name
Address
Date

_________________________________________________________________

http://search.msn.com/results.aspx?q=weather&FORM=WLMTAG

The examples above show the awesome, earning potential of little known companies that explode onto investoor's radar screens; Many of you are already familiar with this. 

Is A UNI poised and positioned to do that for you? Then you may feel the time has come to act... And please watch this one tarde on Monday!

Watch A UNI like a hawk monday at the open!!

Tarde smart and win with AU NI!!! Go AUN I!!

Post ID:4512

Sender:"Geffrey Hernandez" <faz@...>

Post Date/Time:2006-09-18 19:54:52

Subject:comic strip mention

Message:



Damini that evening had completely thrown off her reserve. So Damini had her way, and came along with us.
As for my condition, Damini has left nothing so vague in it as torequire any guess-work. They say it is subject to ghostly visitations.
So we must steer clear of them if we would keep our intellectfree. He raised his eyebrows, as he opened it, and asked: Hullo,Srivilas, what are these for? Satish went to the Masters chamber, and fell to tendinghis feet with fervour. After hisdiscourse had progressed awhile, something in our faces gave himpause.
Whatever my sins may have been, let them not deprive me of the rightto serve you.
The gods,being fortunate, did not feel bound to give it a hearing.
I went and said to Satish: All right, then, let us postpone ourdeparture to town.
Pietywas the one thing Uncle Jagamohan could not tolerate. True, he took up good works asof old; but there was nothing aggressive about it this time.
But, Damini, urged the Swami in his desperation, can I keep youwith me for ever?
But I had not adjusted myself to thedomestic world, like a foot in a comfortable old shoe.
The poormortals whose ears happened to be within reach were woefully agonised.
Nabins wife has taken poison, I think, she said. Through itscracks, wild flowering shrubs have sprung up. She fights shyof Satish because for him her feelings are of the oppositedescription.
The baffled Swami could see, as he passed by the half-open door, acaptive kite in a cage.
There was a festival on at the temple and we hadsupposed that Satish would be there.
I did not come, continued Damini, wanting to please your devotees. The poormortals whose ears happened to be within reach were woefully agonised. This scarcely novel reflection, however, was not what my mindruminated over.
She fights shyof Satish because for him her feelings are of the oppositedescription. The packet was delivered by the postman to theSwami.
If that be a necessity, said I,there must be something radicallywrong with our system. Evening afterevening, pipe after pipe was exhausted, yet the Master was unable tomake up his mind. There were three conditions attached to the bequestwhich I was responsible for carrying out. In one of these Ispread my blanket and laid myself down.
What made it more difficult stillwas that he harboured a secret fear of his ward. Pietywas the one thing Uncle Jagamohan could not tolerate.
For this difference I may have been partly responsible.
I am in awful trouble with the mongoose,she said.
The Master, at heart, begins to be afraid of her again.

H o t st ock allert - This one is still climbing the sotck charts alerrt --  Breaking marekt n e w s report --- VG YI. P K

Companny nname: Viison Enregy Gorup Inc. 
Lookup: VG YI. P K
Current Pricce: $.75
Expected: steadily climb for the top

Breaking N e w s:  

Announcement by Vi sion Ene rgy Grou p: Negotiations Completed on Low BTU Gas Property in Central Valley, CA

Los Angeles --(Bus iness wi re)--Aug. 31, 2006--Pursuant to an agreement of July 2005 between Vis ion Energ y Grou p (Pink Sheets: VGY I) and Valley Production Inc., the seasoned Oil & Gas Production Group from Bakersfield, CA, Visio n En ergy Gr oup has concluded negotiations to jointly process low quality natural gas from two existing wells. A recent third party analysis of these wells gave a remaining reserve in the three production zones of almost 4 billion cubic feet of gas. This will give the project a production life of 10 years at the modest production rate of one million cubic feet per day. Further reserves of gas are anticipated in the surrounding leases after a geophysics and drilling program have been completed.

The gas, which will be upgraded using Vission Energyy Grroup's proprietary technology and know-how, will be so ld as premium grade gas into the statewide pipeline grid. The estimated capital co st of the project is $2.0 million and will be targeted to be in production within seven months.

Valley Production has among its principals and technical staff such notables of the industry as Jeff Smith and Ed LeLousis of Bakersfield, Calif. This production-oriented team will steer Vis ion Ener gy Gr oup, Inc. into the selection of other suitable projects in the San Joaquin Valley, manage and operate the properties and share in the ca sh benefit s on a structured incentive plan.
Visio n Ener gy Grou p, Inc. will beenefit from owning such projects directly or indirectly and by employing their proprietary technology to either liquefy or clean up stranded and/or flared gas from properties that can be acquired at c osts below the normal mark et pri ce. Visioon Energgy Grouup, Inc. is aware that significant reserves of low BTU gas exist in the San Joaquin Valley that can be processed into high quality gas by their systems and readily sold into the pipeline grid.

About Vision Energy Corp.

V ision Energ y Corp. offers an efficient, patented technology to generate electricity at substantial savings by using the wasted energy dissipated when high pressure gas pipelines are let down in pressure for local consumption. Up to 70% of electricity generated when using this system is produced without combustion of any fossil fuel and therefore no harmful atmospheric emissions. Thermal efficiency can exceed 100% by taking advantage of both let down energy and primary turbine waste heat (exhaust ).
